text:
Consider making a reservation for this gem. I called early afternoon Saturday to get in for two that evening around 6:30. Host explained he could get us in at that time in the downstairs area, but not in the dining room upstairs. I was fine with that because it was our first time. My family grew up in Italy and has raved about the food and authenticity! 

The downstairs is where the gelato, coffee bar, other pastries, sandwiches and such are. Generally an area where you can come in and out more quickly than having a sit down dinner, which is what we came for. Aside from that, it is a very pretty ambience. Italian music playing, many songs I grew up listening to which brought me back. 

The waiter explained that each week they chose a region of Italy and create dishes pertaining to that region. One thing I particular looked forward to was the knowledge of staff pairing wine and food as I heard that's what they do. Unfortunately, our waiter did not suggest any wines after we said we were ready to order, but unsure what wine to choose. Our waiter educated us on the man who travels around to hand pick each wine for the restaurant, only to walk away giving us a few more minutes to decide on our own. Hm. 

Ok now for food! Began with classic Italian starters of arancini, rice balls with beef, sauce, peas and cheese, and fritto misto, basically fried calamari with additional fried shrimp and zucchini. Both presented nicely and well cooked. 

We had to order our main dishes with gelato pairings. We went with the ravioli with the back and white truffle gelato and crabcake with red pepper gelato. I was happy with both dishes. My boyfriend thought the ravioli was more al dente than he preferred, but I actually enjoyed the texture. Truffle is very distinct in this dish, so you have to like it if you're going to appreciate the combo with the gelato. I thought the cool gelato complimented each dish nicely. 

For dessert we ordered the brioche gelato sandwich with tiramisu gelato and the sfogliatelle. My boyfriend loved the sandwich and I really liked the texture and taste of sfogliatelle with ricotta filling. It is not a particularly sweet dessert, but very tasty. Only complaint was that the sfogliatelle was supposed to come with whole milk gelato, but it did not. I did realize it after it was served to me, but I did not say anything to the waiter because I suddenly wasn't sure if I was mistaken. Later I checked the menu and they did in fact forget to serve the gelato with my dessert :( Also ordered espresso ristretto, which just means it is stronger. Don't be surprised if it looks like a sip of coffee in a regular size cup. This is the traditional Italian way. 

Service was fine, but nothing too great. I am wondering if it would be a different experience in the actual dining area. 

Overall, the food was delicious. The gelato is out of this world (we sampled a few more on our way out) tremendously full of flavor, but what else could you expect from the gelato champion?! I'm already planning my next meal and brunch too!

Almost overwhelming menu as everything you'd ever want from Italy is here...but when it's delivered to your table, it's nothing you'd ever want to eat.

While looking over the menu, we ordered two mixed drinks; Negroni and an Aperol Spritz.  The Negroni was too heavy on the vermouth and had a full orange slice (a proper Negroni has a burned orange peel to bring out the oil in the skin).  The Aperol was missing the prosecco and bubbles.  We sent them both back and asked to have them removed from the bill, and ordered wine instead.

I started off with the prosciutto de parma and speck alto adage pgi plates.  Both were served in identical fashion, thin strips laid over a salad and on a wooden cutting board.  The salad had a purplish and thick dressing on it, resembled a balsamic like flavor, but way too sweet and overpowering for the light side salad.  It also had green olives in it that didn't fit the flavor profile.  At $9.50 per plate, this was way overpriced.

The "Salumi Sushi", I had the Friuli dish, prosciutto and strawberries wrapped in a roll and then sliced down like a sushi roll, a balsamic reduction in between.  Not a bad dish, but at $11 for the dish, it was again a little overpriced.

The Fritto Misto was average, but not what I was expecting for an authentic Italian restaurant.  The calamari and zucchini were good, but the shrimp were the really small previously frozen kind and ruined the dish.

The mozzarella dish was buffalo mozzarella, we chose "caprese".  It was 1/4 of a ball of mozzarella, then cut into 4 smaller pieces and placed at the corners of the plate while a tomato/green olive/pine nut mixture dominated the center of the plate.  At $11, I expect a whole ball of mozzarella (a ball of buffalo mozzarella costs $6 wholesale).  Huge failure here.  Just go to Di Bruno's down the street and get a full cheese serving if you're after a cheese plate.

Next up was their "ROME" special of the week.  The waiter explained that they picked a different region every week and featured dishes and wines specific to that region.  I opted to try the Spaghetti Carbonara.  What I received looked good, except for a scoop of bacon gelato on top.  The pasta itself was slightly overcooked, missing that slight "thickness" that properly cooked pasta in Italy has.  Maybe they're just using cheap boxed pasta instead of making it fresh?  The sauce was too much egg and not enough liquid, maybe by removing the bacon from the dish, they lost the bacon fat which kept the sauce thinner?  Combine the cool pasta temperature and the cold gelato on top, this dish was a huge failure.

The parmigiano ravioli also came with gelato on top.  This was supposed to be yellow tomato with basil but it tasted like some form of mango (and way too sweet).  Again, the cold gelato on top of the lukewarm pasta was an unpleasant combination.  The ravioli's were also overcooked and I'd swear they were a prepackaged and previously frozen pasta.  We ate one bite and left the dish.

The meal at this point was so disappointing, we skipped the post dinner espresso and the gelato they're famous for.  The check came to a shocking $180 with the tip, and we would have been hungry except for the pains in our stomach from the unpleasant meal...

The interior space is very nice looking.  We were told it was made in Italy, and then shipped here for assembly.  Impressive...but what would have been more impressive, and more effective, would have been to bring over an actual Italian chef instead of serving what tastes like pre-packaged pasta and foodservice prepared foods.

I have to start by saying that other than a big love of all things Italian and the fact that I stalked this place as it was being built, and hope it remains successful, I hold no stake or stock in the restaurant even though my raving review will make you think someone paid me to say these things. I tried to cut this short but just couldn't so stick it out, read on, and enjoy Gran Caffe'!
Since the Caffe' opened in December, I don't think I've missed a week (it is conveniently near my office)  so I've tried a lot of food, beverages, and desserts on the menu and I can't say enough about it.
When you walk in you can completely suspend reality and pretend you are right in Italy. The decor is gorgeous and it is set up downstairs just like an Italian Caffe'. The upstairs elegant dining room continues the effect with Italian books on the shelves. Then when you take a sip of espresso, you will really think you have flown to Italy! This coffee, in my opinion is the best in America...imported and roasted right on the premises.  The Italian wine menu is so thorough, extensive, and varied and the prices are amazing for Center City. 
Now on to the food. This is true blue from Italy Italian. No fettucine alfredo here!!! The food is so fresh that I've tasted foods here that I can otherwise be a little leery of eating. I haven't had a bite of anything that wasn't delicious. There is always a weekly special menu highlighting a certain town in Italy. Everything is so unique. A couple of my favorites were the Florentine steak (served on a cutting board-very creative) and the pici which because it is hand rolled it is very hard to find on a menu here in the US. The pasta is all hand made in house and incredible. I also had a Food Network moment with a warm melon dish where my tongue was tasting the whole spectrum of flavors which I always thought was so funny on those competition shows and now I know it can happen. I can't say enough about the time and care put into the recipes and the execution.  On the standard menu the gnocchi melt in your mouth and the zuppe di pesce makes one of my friends want to stand up and applaud the chef! The eggplant parmigiana is perfect. The crab cakes are also a treat. Then there is the gelato, made by the World Master (really, no joke). This gelato is better than any I tasted in Italy. Each type is so saturated with fresh flavors that you think you are eating the actual food it is named after. The pistacchio tastes like the actual nuts, the fondente tastes like a delicious dark chocolate bar, you get the idea. So many flavors to choose from also. It is truly an art.
The wait staff work hard and do a great job in a big place with 2 floors to serve. Shout out to Rob, Matthew, Taka, Agnieszka, Sam, and Luciano is at the bar! You can even come here for cultural classes and an occasional Italian karaoke night. So, if you need a moment in Italy and can't get there right now, head over to Gran Caffe', you won't be disappointed! Ciao.

Chiming in on a review that I came across for this establishment about racism. I visited on June 9, 2018 and chose this since it was in close proximity to my hotel in Center City. I met two ditzy hostesses that body checked me in the weirdest manner and led me all the way to the back of the restaurant after telling them I wanted coffee and a snack. It was around 11AM and there were only three parties in total sprawled across the restaurant. Strike 1: what makes you think I want to sit in a dimly lit area when it is bright and 80 degrees outside?

They told me to go all the way in the back, so I oblige since I'm hungry. I wait and the blond waitress with a bun refuses to acknowledge us. She glares and looks pissed and angrily questions, "Do you plan to order or something?" Strike 2: she watches us sit, stares at us, refuses to initiate conversation, sees us looking around for a menu, senses our confusion, and when she does approach us, she gives the nastiest attitude. Sorry for thinking you could serve me? Like what?

We tell her we're waiting to see a menu. At this point, she questions why we didnt get one. I'm baffled at this point. Instead of giving us one, she goes to the hostesses only for one of them to come back to make a point about getting coffee? It was intrusive, and only added to my level of discomfort. Strike 3.

The waitress returns and throws a single menu at us. A single menu for two people. Strike 4.

This was the most uncomfortable experience. Everyone there was white and my skin is tan. It was cold and uninviting since the moment I came in. I left after she threw the menu. Before leaving I had taken a look at my surroundings. The people at the bar were conversing with the patrons seated there. The hostesses were nice to lighter skinned people. Our waitress just didnt want to serve brown skinned people, since it's apparently so beneath her. 

I called to speak with a manager and was interrogated so much before I finally was able to. The people working there realized how big they screwed up, and the hostesses were prying so hard to figure out who I was and why I need a manager. Ned, the manager, apologized and told me to give them another chance. After reading the lower ratings for this place I am certain this place needs to address why its staff treats darker skinned people so poorly in comparison to its caucasian customers. 

Its 2018. If you're still branded as a racist in America then I wish you luck, but you are not going to see any good come out of this.

Overall, I thought the food was great but there were a few things that kept me from giving a higher rating. First, when you walk in, it is confusing where you should go. It looked like downstairs was the gelato shop so we walked upstairs only to be brought back downstairs to the hostess. It was not obvious that this is what we were supposed to do. Once being brought back upstairs to sit down we were immediately greeted by our server.
I have to say that these poor servers look a little ridiculous in their Pinocchio hats and suspenders. Once I got past that, it took the server sooooo long to explain what the history of the restaurant and the idea behind the menu was. In my opinion, if you have to do a lot of explaining, then maybe the concept needs to be revisited so it is more clear. Is it small plates? Is it for sharing? Are you supposed to order items from several different areas of the menu? Will this be enough food? Who knows, it was all very, very confusing.
Also, our waiter was annoyingly attentive. He left so we could look at the menu and came back two or three times before we had a chance to make up our minds. He stood like six feet away while we discussed what we thought might be good and interjected every once in a while with some information or opinions. It was uncomfortable, I have never had a waiter do that before. 
Whatever the waiter said to us in his long explanation was lost on us. We ended up looking at it from a more traditional stand point. We ordered an appetizer, some dinner salads and an entree. I eavesdropped when the table next to us was ordering and it seemed like they were equally confused asking if that was going to be enough food and if they had ordered correctly.
Anyway, now to the food. We thought we had ordered lamb skewers to start but four shrimp in a spicy barbecue like sauce were brought to our table. There must have been something lost in the translations. We didn't say anything and ate it. They were plump and tasted great. My salad was large and had a bunch of some bitter vegetable in it and a weak citrus dressing. I mostly picked around and left about half of it. For the entree I had the branzino fish plate. It came with asparagus and roast potatoes. This dish was altogether delicious and I enjoyed it very much. I also ordered a scoop of cafe gelato. Best gelato I have ever had. It was so good, if I had not been so full I would have wanted more. 
It is a bit of an expensive meal. It was $96 before tip. If our waiter had not been such a weirdo and there was less confusion I think I would have scored higher based on the food.

We walked in and requested a table for 3. The two? three? hostesses looked really confused, but then told us they were going to seat us upstairs in a few minutes. My friend told them we only wanted desserts, and then they looked confused again. They said upstairs seating is for dinner only, no desserts. Since there was an empty table about 10ft away from us, we asked if we could just have that table and bring a chair over. And again, they're still confused. We were about to go grab a chair and bring it over ourselves, but one of them managed to do that.

So we're kind of sitting there, ready to order about 15 minutes ago, while the hostesses are just standing there 10ft away from us dillydallying. My friend gets up to go to the counter/bakery case to order our desserts since no one was doing their job, then a waitress finally appeared to take our order. We told her that he was already over there ordering, and she asked if we were dining in or taking out? We said dining in. So she runs over to the counter to tell those guys that my friend, who is ordering at the moment, that his order was for dining in.

A few minutes later, my friend's Macedonia was brought to us. It's basically a fruit salad with a lot of juice and a small scoop of gelato served in a small sundae glass. A couple more minutes go by.. maybe 10-15, and our other desserts haven't come. The waitress has completely disappeared and we didn't even have water during this entire time. At this point, we're tired of waiting and decide to leave. We left enough money to cover the $8.90 + tax for the Macedonia. We never even saw the bill. 

What confuses me is that the creme brulee (one of the two desserts we never got), were already made and on display. I wanted to like this place but the lack of communication and a bunch of people not doing their jobs has turned me away.

THE AMERICANIZATION OF GRAN CAFFE L
AQUILLA.
I was so excited to see a real Italian cafe arriving from Rome.
We live just two blocks away and I already knew that this would be our neighborhood bistro.
We were not disappointed with our first visit a week after they opened. Pasta that was Al'dente, flavors that were the real thing.  Eveything done as if one where in Italy.
The second time, we brough friends who were just delighted as were we.
The third time we came with more friends and loved it all.
The fourth time, not so much, but hey anyone can have an off night.
The fifth time, when I saw the addition of the ubiquitous dessert tray, I knew that instead of remaining true to Italy, they were trying to assimilate to American tastes.
Last night 3/14/15, we arrived at 6:15.  We had to wait for a table upstairs. Yes, and those stairs. Only for the fittest and waiters transfer food from the downstairs kitchen, up the stairs, to your waiter.  It passes through many hands before you get it.
We had to wait a long time for everything.

On a Saturday night, at six PM, our waiter's station had not been supplied with plates or silverware!!!!!!!!!

My husband ordered soup, and I was delighted to see Blue Points on the menu.
I asked the waiter how many oysters were in one order.  He said "six."  There were five on the plate and he said that sometimes he sees six on a plate and sometimes five. I thought those things should have been settled in the kitchen and made known to the servers.
The chef had adulterated the oysters with flavors and something sweet so that it taste like anything but oysters. Because I said I expected oysters, the owner sent up another five.  Yes, they were plain with adulterated cocktail sauce but were not the taste of great Blue Points.  I did not finish all.
I ordered spaghetti with clams, I dish that they once served me enough to swoon for. This time, it was not the same in the quality of the clams nor the presentation.
My husband's Bolognese sauce had less meat.

If you want Gelatto for dessert, you have to rush down the steps to look at the Gellato case and then upstairs to your waiter.  Twice I did not get what I wanted.

What a shame.  Totally uncoordinated, this restaurant opened without all it's ducks in place.  People kept coming but everything is now rush rush get it out of the kitchen. Waiters running everywhere.  An accident waiting to happen.  Downstairs at the food bar, we heard a huge crash.  Looks like a coffee machine hit the floor.
This was the best and could have remained so, but there is only time now to count the money.

My mom and sister took me here for my birthday on a Monday evening in early February. This was our first time here, for dinner. In the past, I have been here for snacks, coffee or lunch and not had an issue. 
In short, the food was excellent, the service could not have been worse: 

They seated us in a very dark spot on the second floor and I was seated directly behind a wait staff area where they store tray tables. ALL night long my seat was banged by people taking the tray table in and out. 

We were beside a large party which was very loud so we asked to move tables and they said they couldn't accommodate. Ok then. We ordered appetizers and wine, upon finishing the waitress came and took our plates and I asked if she could clean the table as I had gotten bruschetta and there were crumbs everywhere. She brought a rag to wipe the table and my mom and sister lifted their bread plates and wine for her to wipe their area too. She looked at them after she wiped my area and walked away  We all looked at each other like "what is this girls problem!?" 

We ordered dinner and I asked for my pasta without meat. It came with meat and they left my mom and sisters dishes on the table and took mine to the kitchen to replace. My mom had to call the waitress over again to ask her to keep the dishes warm as they weren't about to start eating without everyone's dinner on the table. The waitress doesn't say a word, rolls her eyes at us and takes their dishes back. Then my food comes and we eat. The back of my chair is still being banged away by the wait staff and tray tables. 

We order desert and it comes, with a candle. The waitress stands at the head of the table and starts laughing (by herself) and singing happy birthday in English then some guy joins her for a sentence then randomly walks away and she can barely rush through the song fast enough to leave. Then she just walks away, no "enjoy your desert" "happy birthday" nothing... 

I still can't figure out why she was laughing and so incredibly rude to us. 

Ugh, I couldn't wait to leave! I really felt sad after this meal and was so looking forward to a great birthday meal, great service, in a great atmosphere. It was horrible.

Find parking, take the train, or get yourself an Uber/Lyft  and just make a "B" line to Gran Caffe L'Aquilla! That is all you need to know, because what ever you get from here will simply be AMAZING! I see you are still looking at my review waiting for some more information than the whole "B" line shtick. I suppose a picture or 2 might stimulate your appetite to know more about Gran Caffe. Let's get serious now my Yelp family, serious like a kid to funnel cake serious. Get a glass of your favorite wine, because this will not be a short review. 

                                              ~Appetizers~  
*Polipo (Grilled Octopus) ~ This savory appetizer had me moaning I tell you. Picture getting punched in the face, but with out the pain that follows a punch. If perfection had a picture to follow it, this dish is it.
*Arancini ~ A decadent Sicilian dish, which is a lightly fried rice ball. A rice ball made in a ragu, which is stuffed with a mixture of veal and pork. All being held together with mozzarella cheese, laying over top their sauce mixed with peas for added pleasures. 
*Arrosticini Abruzzese ~ Your choice of either chicken or lamb with this dish folks. Lamb for the win, with their Calabrese dipping sauce that had a subtle kick to it. Honestly dipping it, or not, it's still badass.

                                              ~Our Meals~
The "Gelato" Pairings is something that needs to be taken advantage of it immediately. This is literally biblical, where you will be singing praises to the Gods above. The creativity, and uniqueness can not be described on Yelp. I implore you to order a dish from this amazing menu. Basically any dish from this sectioned off menu will be a winning dish.
                                              My Gelato Pairing
*Agnoletti al Tartufo ~ This elegant dish is homemade raviolis stuffed with veal, pork, onions with an herb that had me wanting to scream out obscenities with that butter sage sauce. The gelato that was paired with this dish is their black and white truffle gelato. You mix the gelato with your dish and you've just brought this to a whole new level of satisfaction.  Yelpers, this sinful combination, this dynamic duo will make you feel like you are having an affair. 1 word, 3 syllables. De-lic-ious... Delicious. 
*Insalata Pera ~ For a salad this larger than life dish of greens with fruits was on point. A fresh crisp succulent pear that just did numbers to ones taste buds, with the goat cheese mixed in there making me rethink how a salad should always taste.  
                                                   ~Dessert~ 
*Brioche con Gelato ~ This dessert is actually a gelato sandwich, with your choice of 2 scoops of gelato. I went with a Bacio gelato and an Amaretto gelato, being held nicely in a toasted brioche bun. To be honest this was ok, the brioche seemed a little too dry, and the gelato not so creamy. This is not a slam on Gran Caffe, with everything that have to offer, but it seemed a little off to me. I will say this though, their dessert menu looks amazing, with endless options. 
 
Unique dishes that will have your taste buds going into full tilt mode along with their weekly tasting menu. Their tasting menu is designed to bring you through different regions of Italy, experiencing the dishes from that region. If that doesn't raise an eyebrow you should checkout their happy hour menu, and specials. I feel Gran Caffe L'Aquilla is an establishment that needs to be a part of your rotation. The last few times I've been here the staff has always made sure I, or we have been fully accommodated. Hopefully you're seated in Corina or Anastaysia area, but if not, don't fret their staff will make sure you'll have the very best dining experience. I know I plan on coming back every time I come home to visit.

**Side Note** My Gelato Pairing was not an easy decision to make.

I'm not a fan of dining out on Valentine's day, but Gran Caffe L'Aquila made it worthwhile.  I don't want to deal with crowds or menus that are easier on the chefs to mass produce and push out.  Not this place though.  They offer such a wide variety of their menu and they change it up every week with a special visit to Italian Cities.  For Valentine's day, we were treated to a trip in Verona, home of Romeo and Juliet.  It's so fitting too, because Romeo and Juliet plays such a vital part in my marriage.  My wife and I both know that if we think the other one is dead, to not drink poison and just wait it out...  Most likely one of us is just sleeping...  No need to make a tragedy out of laziness...  

Anyways, we were greeted right away and although we were about twenty minutes early for our reservation, we were promptly seated upstairs.  Our waitress introduced herself and explained the menu.  We really needed a game plan on how to maximize our happiness and we figured out the best way to do that.  I started off with the Bigoli Al Rosemarino.  Bigoli pasta with a duck ragu, with some rosemary and ricotta gastronomic gelato mixed in.  SERIOUSLY...  Savory gelato in the shape of a heart, that I was supposed to break up and mix into my pasta.  It added a nice touch and well worth it.  My wife also went with a Gelato pairing, but not from the Verona menu.  She got the Agnoletti al tartufo with a black and white truffle gelato.  Both were great.  

I didn't know what to get for my entree, but I went with the Veal Saltimboca.  It was the perfect thickness and had a great taste.  A nice sage and wine sauce accompanied it.  I love veal and it's not always great, but this place does it right.  The wife got some duck breast with blood orange.  I enjoyed the skin, but mine was definitely better.  

For drinks, we both went with the Sgroppino, which had lemon sorbetto mint, some lemoncino vodka and prosecco.  It was light and refreshing.  After our meal, I enjoyed a shot of espresso with chocolate and mint.  My wife ordered a cappuccino with caramel sauce.  To finish the meal, we both enjoyed two scoops of Gelato.  We held some discussions prior to ordering and I advised against trying to mix flavors.  Sometimes you can get too creative and it just doesn't work...  We were offered the choice of mixing flavors and might as well throw all logic out...  I mixed the chocolate covered Strawberry with the dark chocolate gelato, while my wife also had dark chocolate, but with cherry.  Both were so smooth and delicious.  Fantastic gelato.  

Everyone was just so friendly here and patient.  I think the manager came over three times to us.  My major complain was that I am assuming my wife's family was sitting directly behind me, because there was someone who kept on sneezing so incredibly loud during their meal.  Great service and food.  Can't be better than that.  A great Valentine's day meal!

Alert!! :  If you are looking for 4 1/2 - star gelato and panini, then maybe you are in the right place, but the upstairs restaurant should not be included in that rating.

We found this highly-rated Italian restaurant on Yelp and it was close to our hotel, so we tried it. As soon as we sat down and the waiter started-in with his spiel I got a bad vibe. A bit of that "pretentious" vibe. The host who greeted us (a really nice and genuine fellow) did so with a few Italian words mixed-in, with an authentic accent, and I thought he was Italian. Then I hear him across the room revert to a normal American accent. What? What was that show of Italian language for? It just felt contrived, that's all.

So our waiter brings us menus and explains them, and we now understand that many of the prices we had previewed on Yelp were for "tapas-like" portions. That's why it seemed inexpensive. But we stay.

The waiter: "Any questions?"
Wife: "Yes -- between the (listed entree), the (listed entree), and the (listed entree)..."  [looks at waiter]
Waiter:  "What's the question?"

(Strike one.)

Wife:  "Which is your favorite?"
Waiter then seems to struggle with recommendations. Wife chooses.
Waiter looks at me...
Me: "I'm looking at five things..." (I list them)
Waiter: "What's the question?"

(Strike two.)

We discuss...
Me: "Is that one like an Amatriciana sauce?"
Waiter: "What?"
Me: "A-mat-ri-ciana -- bacon-tomato sauce..."
Waiter: "Oh! I just learned that word yesterday..."
Me: "OK, there you go..."
Waiter: "Well, it doesn't have the pesto in it..."
Me, interrupting: "Pesto???!..."
Waiter: "Amatriciana typically has a pesto base to it, but this one doesn't."
Me: "An ITALIAN guy made Amatriciana for me, and it doesn't have pesto in it. -- Maybe in *some* region they make it like that..."  (allowing him to save face)

(Strike three.)

I decide upon tagliatelle alla panna, a safe choice.

Waiter brings bread.
Me: "Can I have some butter for the bread?"
Waiter: "It's typically served with olive--"
Me: "I know. I want some butter, please."

(Strike four.)

And that's kinda how it went. My entree was good; my wife's was just weird, with that bit of gelato on top of the pasta. It doesn't work, I'm sorry. She said it was interesting, but I would have thrown it out rather than eat it, and I'm in love with all things pasta. 

So, to sum it up, I didn't experience a 4-1/2 star restaurant. Stay away from pasta with gelato and the waiter with an attitude and you might fare better.

Came here for my boyfriend's birthday dinner earlier this year, and I've been wanting to come back ever since! Just the other day, I found an excuse to pop in for some gelato. This versatile establishment is amazing for a fancy Italian dinner, a casual cafe meet-up, or (as I've just discovered) ordering delivery!

DINNER/UPSTAIRS: My boyfriend is a huge fan of Italian food, so I was searching around on Yelp for a romantic, upscale (but not TOO expensive) Italian restaurant to treat him at for his birthday. The great Yelp reviews brought Gran Caffe L'Aquila to my attention, and several other online listings dubbing it one of the most romantic places to dine in Philly sealed the deal. You'll definitely need a reservation if you plan on dining upstairs. We were seated promptly by the pleasant waitstaff. They were so thoughtful and accommodating - I wasn't totally satisfied with where we were seated, so the hostess moved us to a nicer place in the courtyard. However, she noticed that it was quite loud, and offered to move us (before we had ordered anything) to a different area. Our waiter was also excellent. Service definitely sets Gran Caffe L'Aquila apart.

Food-wise, we had the decadent Italian meal we were hoping for. We started with Fritto Misto, which is calamari jazzed up with some shrimp and zucchini. Portions are a bit smaller than your typical Italian eatery, but that's in conjunction with stellar food presentations to reflect an upscale, fine-dining feel. The Fritto Misto was just enough to whet my appetite for our beautiful pastas. We opted to order from Maestro Biasini's Gelato Pairings, "culinary specialties paired with savory gelato, prepared by the Italiant Gelato Champion" - super unique, so obviously we had to try! The Carbonara w/ Bacon Gelato is the dish topped w/ the bacon spiral I'd been eyeing via Yelp - did not disappoint, there's a reason there are so many pictures of it! The savory Bacon Gelato was more of a frozen heavy cream that melted and stirred in. My personal favorite was the Agnoletti al Tartufo - veal/pork stuffed ravioli w/ black and white truffle gelato (because truffle makes everything better). Again, the gelato is meant as more of a cream/sauce, but this one was served w/ about a teaspoon of white truffle oil in the middle. Because the gelato melted slowly, we were able to enjoy the creamy ravioli without being overwhelmed by the truffle flavor - genius!

For dessert, we finished with the Affogato (a scoop of ice cream in a shot of espresso) and White Chocolate Brioche Banana Bread Pudding. Both are usually served with Fior di Latte gelato (i.e. Milk/Plain), but you can sub it out for any flavor you want! We opted for Tiramisu gelato in the Affogato and Salted Caramel gelato with our bread pudding. I was a bit disappointed by how small the desserts were, given how pricey they are. However, I have to say THE ESPRESSO IS MIND-BLOWING. I usually don't think fancy espresso shots are worth it, but I would 100% drop the dough for one of these, with or without gelato. Loved the bread pudding, but it's definitely on the lighter side - highly recommend to those of y'all who don't like overly sweet desserts.

CAFE/DOWNSTAIRS: If you don't have a reservation, or want to pop in for a more casual setting, the downstairs area has a decent amount of seating. Behind the counter is a beautiful selection of gelato, pastries/desserts, and sandwiches. You can order coffee, as well as full pasta dishes from the full menu! I absolutely LOVE the gelato selection. Salted Caramel was a seasonal flavor, unfortunately, but it's probably my favorite gelato flavor EVER. It satisfies my sweet tooth but isn't cloyingly sweat or heavy. A close second is the Tiramisu Gelato, which is always available (thank God). To compare to Capogiro, the flavor selection is definitely less varied (you won't get as many interesting fruity/herbal combinations) in keeping with a more traditional Italian theme. I happen to love various combinations of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and nuts, so I think the selection is perfect.

DELIVERY: TBD, definitely keeping this on my order-in list for my next lazy night ;)

To sum it up, you really can't go wrong with Caffe Gran L'Aquila, no matter what you're looking for. Excited to return to eat my way through the rest of the pasta menu and gelato flavors, as well as a lovely shot of espresso when I'm feeling fancy!

It's been a while since I've been to a real Italian café, however Gran Caffe L'Aquila takes me back to my trip to Italy. 

I heard that the bar area was standing room only and did not have seats, which is was a concern for my husband on crutches in a boot. I called the restaurant prior and they were able to set us up with a reservation in the bar area, even though they typically don't do that for Sips. As it turns out, they do have seats at the bar, however we didn't learn that until we passed some empty seats on our way out. 

Upon arrival our table wasn't ready at the time of our reservation. We had to wait about 10 minutes to be seated. They also weren't able to place us as close to the bar as we had requested, so unfortunately we weren't near our friends who we had wanted to spend time with. Despite closing menus and trying to make contact with every server who walked by, it took about 10 minutes for anyone to check on us. We were about ready to leave, when our server came over and offered his apologies. I'm glad we stayed...

The experience from there on out was charming. Ordering off the Sips menu to start, I went with the Salice Salentino red wine. It was not on their regular menu, but enjoyable. I found it to be dry, but have a slight sweetness to it as well. According to a quick internet search it's supposed to be a pretty cheap wine, but it was still Italian so whatever. I had the Melanzana Parmigiana off of the Sips menu as well. I'm a sucker for eggplant and this dish consisting of eggplant, ricotta, mozzarella and tomato sauce did not disappoint. Give me 3 or 4 of them and it could have been a meal. 

Since we were comfortable at the table and enjoying ourselves we decided to venture into their dinner menu and went with the Pappardelle al Ragu Aquilano. Now I'm no stranger to this dish, and this execution of the ragu was excellent. Often you can get a bunch of "mixed meat" that is undecipherable, but you could really individualize the pork, veal, lamb and chicken while still retaining the general flavor. It was a nice portion to share after each having an appetizer. I would think it would be quite filling when eaten solo. 

Now as you may know, I'm not the biggest dessert person, but thoroughly enjoyed my tiramisu flavored gelato. There's something about a unique, house-produced sweet that has me second guessing my whole stance. Splitting the small hit the spot. 

We both left the café full, but not stuffed. I could only imagine how filling a full three-course meal could be there. 

After the initial service snafu, we couldn't have asked for more out of our server. Despite a crowded dining room, he was polite, professional and attentive as he could be. 

Thoroughly charmed by Gran Caffee L'Aquila, I look forward to a return visit.

Restaurant week review
3 stars for food
2 stars for wait time for food
4 stars for waiter

Ambience: I came with a friend for indoor dining at 5PM over the weekend for Restaurant Week. The restaurant is beautifully decorated with much bigger seating inside on the second floor than expected. The overall noise level is well controlled to slightly loud, just not too crazy as the night progressed. My friend thought she couldn't hear the waiter too well at the start of the night - so maybe I'd say it's mixed.

We were promptly seated with our reservation.

Service: Our waiter offered detailed reviews and thoughts of the menu. The actual pacing of the food was quite delayed. For a four course meal, it literally took 2 hours from us sitting down to actually receiving the dessert. At least 10-15 minutes of down time was noted between each course.

Food: 
Bread for the table - the olive oil had a slightly tart taste, bread I would have preferred toasted

First course: we ordered the cheese plate and the meat plates (Sud Italia and Salumi Verticale) 
For the salumi (meat plate) - I think two of the meats had a decent taste, but two were misses for me - they're okay samples but don't exactly pair with the cheese plates
For the cheese plates - the pecorino has a nice strong taste that stands out on its own, but it's quite overpowering. The capra and caciocavallo were a bit underwhelming and subtle flavored. The fig & strawberry marmolade crostini had a slightly negative tart aftertaste that was a bit unpleasant.

Second course: Cinghiale - wild boar meatballs - these had a nice solid taste for a meatball. Unfortunately our dish was served lukewarm. 
Carciofi fritti - flash fried artichoke - I think these almost tasted like a potato wedge with that slight artichoke flavor, it was nice to dip with the tomato sauce from the meatballs

Third course: Arrosticini biasini - lamb and bacon skewers - again great flavor for the lamb (my personal favorite protein), but unfortunately was also a bit lukewarm. The spicy mustard gelato on the side was a bit overpowering, and I don't think it necessarily paired with the skewers to my liking. Almost like a wasabi.

Gnocchi - beautifully pillowy texture, the mushrooms were tender. There was a delightful truffle scent and I think this was the star of the meal.

Fourth course: 
Gelato - we asked for the cheesecake alla fragola (strawberry cheesecake with crumble) and cocco e rhum (coconut and rum) - but our waiter brought out a nutella flavor - which unfortunately did not pair well with the strawberry like the coconut. He did bring out the correct gelato when we corrected him. This was a much better choice, but there wasn't much of a rum flavor. The strawberry was nice. The gelato texture overall was melt-in-your-mouth good.

Gran panna cotta - A bit heavier than other panna cotta's I've had, there is a nice espresso/chocolate flavor, and it was a nice ending to the meal.

Tips/Takeaways:
-Probably would not return, but worth a try at least once - filling meal for the $40 restaurant week pricing
-First course: probably would not get the meat or cheese plates
-Second course: I was satisfied with our meatball and artichoke combo
-Third course: I think I would rather have tried their other pasta dishes considering how good the gnocchi was
-Fourth course: The gelato I think was a better choice than the panna cotta
-Service: Unfortunately, quite slow which negatively impacted the experience of the meal
-Wait staff - well informed and friendly

Tonight was my second time here, and after having experienced drinks, food and service, I'm ready to write a review- and its a great one!
Both of my visits to Gran Caffe l'Aquila were work-related (just another reason I love my job). The first time was a summer happy hour, which was when I tried the Gran Gianduiotto Gran Caffe L'Aquilla/Levante stout, which might just be my favorite stout beer ever. (It's dessert-y but not cloyingly so - if you're a stout fan, do yourself a favor and get it). The ambiance was very nice, my party being seated towards the back of the first floor, where it was extra bustling with servers flying to and fro carrying platters of food and drink (sometimes to us, but mostly we were kind of in their way which I felt bad about, especially because they were so nice about it). The wine selection was tempting, but I'm a one drink-per happy hour girl (at least these days). The prices are what you would expect for a nice Italian restaurant kind of experience, but the quality definitely lives up to them, so very worth it.
Today's visit was for the office holiday party. Same location, same bustle. This time I partook of the food though, and I was very glad I did because everything I ate was completely delicious. The eggplant caponata bruschetta was as perfect, cooked just right and full of flavor, and the and tomato basil bruschetta was served with burrata mozzarella, the combination of which was so good I had to stop myself from going after the plates of my distracted colleagues. Being in the mood for a lighter drink, I had a glass of prosecco this time, and it was crisp and refreshing without screaming summer - a good sparkling wine for the winter too (although at 55 degrees today, what kind of winter is this?)
The food and drinks are all great, but I must acknowledge a truly personable and thoughtful waitstaff as well. As a vegetarian, I wasn't able to indulge in the meatier dishes offered, but I was pretty darn happy with my decadent bread and cheese (and those sinfully seasoned tomatoes). But one server in particular went above and beyond, bringing out dishes of sauteed mushrooms, broccoli rabe and asparagus, JUST for me and my other vegetarian colleagues (I think there are two). Given that this was a substitution from the original order, completely unasked for and unexpected, I am extra appreciative. I'll be making more trips to Gran Caffe l'Aquila (without my colleagues this time) for more happy experiences like these.

I came here for restaurant week with a close friend and it was such a memorable experience! If you're looking for an aesthetic dinner place with "city vibes," this would be an excellent place to go.

WORTH FOR PRICE POINT: 5/5
I have gone to many restaurant weeks, and this was the only restaurant I've experienced with a FOUR-COURSE meal (normally restaurants offer 3 courses). For its four-courses, this was pretty worth it for only $35! The portions were well-sized that I even had left overs to bring home for lunch the next day. I highly recommend checking this restaurant out during restaurant week - you won't regret it!

SERVICE: 5/5
Wonderful! When we asked for balsamic vinegar to go along with the olive oil with our friend, they were very accommodating. When we asked for extra bread, they said they couldn't guarantee because they were almost running out, but they were able to bring out extra bread for us! When I asked the server to take photos of my friend and I, she took quality photos from all different angles - this is probably one of the best experiences I've had with having my photo taken by a "stranger." The server even asked us if the photos were to our liking before going to another table. 

For dessert, I couldn't decide which flavor I wanted so I was able to taste-test. I tasted SO MANY flavors (at least 10 different flavors) and the employees did not even seem a bit annoyed. They were extremely generous with the taste test quantity too! I'm very grateful.

FOOD: 4/5
The only reason why I'd give this place a 4 instead of a 5 is because of the food taste. Don't get me wrong - everything was delicious, but some of the food tasted like what you normally would expect in a well-made dish. I'd give a 5 if there was something in that dish that would set it apart from a dish that I had somewhere else. Here's a run-down of my impression:

Bread - 2/5 A bit dry/stale. Not the best bread I've had. But it was nice that they were able to give us two of them.

FIRST COURSE:
Bruschette - 5/5 delicious! Would recommend giving this a try! The blend of fruity with grainy taste was a nice surprise. I really enjoyed this.

Salumi Verticale - 3/5 it was my first time having cut Italian meat. The meat itself was great. I did not enjoy the block of cheese as much (I'm lactose in tolerant). The complementary salad they included was average. When you ate the meat, cheese, and salad all together, it did go together very nicely. 

SECOND COURSE:
Cinghiale - 4/5 These meatballs are worth a try! Very good meatballs. What I liked the most was the pinge of slight spiciness at the very end - this was a nice surprise!

Carciofi Fritti - 5/5 Artichokes. I LOVED THESE!! Highly, highly recommend. Very flavorable. With the lemon juice squeezed on top, it was very tasty.  This was one of my favorite dishes of the night.

THIRD COURSE:
Arrostinini Biasini - 4.5/5 Lamb skewers. It was my first time having lamb skewers and I can not stop thinking about them! They were very, very tasty, and the mustard gelato that was served with them was the perfect condiment to bring out the flavor. This was my other favorite dish of the night.

Agnoletti Al Tartufo - 4/5 Gnocci. These were delicious. A little bit on the heavier side, but well-made. I haven't tried many gnocci in my life, but all the ones I've tried tasted like this one.

DESSERT
Gelato - 5/5 Amazing flavor, texture. I got the Mango and the Caffe scoops. While the fruit flavor doesn't mix well with the sweet flavor, both were DELICIOUS. I would come back here for the dessert in a heart beat.

Tiramisu - 5/5 This was not on the menu, but the server mentioned they offered it! Tiramisu is one of my favorite desserts, and this did not disappoint. It's a pretty large portion!

The service and quality has really fallen off a cliff in the three years since I last reviewed Gran Caffe--when it was relatively new to the Philly scene. While I can't say I'm completely surprised by its downward trajectory, as most new establishments lose focus on keeping their customers happy and more on their bottom line, the overall customer service has become noticeably more apathetic and sometimes downright negligent.

The menu has remained relatively unchanged over the past few years, and though the food hasn't noticeably depreciated, it is a far cry from the standards and variety that they had a few years ago. Just for comparison's sake, in 2016 and '17, they provided a new menu with offerings from a different region in Italy every few weeks. Whether they ran out of places or just became too lazy to revamp their menu, the offerings have become quite standard--becoming essentially a glorified café.

The coffee and gelato, too, have become increasingly monetarized. Whereas before there used to be a pretty design in the top of every latté and the blends had stronger fruit accents, both are now gone... When I returned this morning for one last try on a completely empty Sunday morning, the servers displayed little attention and spent more time idling on their phones than actually paying attention to ordering or waiting customers.

As for the gelato, it is clear that their "Gelato Champion" Stefano Biasini is attempting to cash in on his recent gelato successes. As they advertise his name recognition more heavily and incorporate that cost into their prices across-the-board, the value has dropped noticeably. It remains decent gelato, but is it worth it anymore? Not in my book, go for any other dessert in Reading Terminal Market if you want glorified ice cream.

The service is truly what has dragged Gran Caffe down the most, however. As I hear patrons complaining about how the wait staff has--on repeated occasions--lost credit cards and regularly taken half an hour to take orders and then bring food during even off-peak hours, it is clear that management cares more about profits than retaining customers.

Is Gran Caffe still worth a try for first-timers? Perhaps. For Philadelphia regulars though? I doubt it. The Philly food scene has long moved past Gran Caffe L'Aquila and its rapidly plunging standards of quality and value.

So, we had VERY high hopes for this.  First off, the only reservation we could make was for outdoor seating and figured that the restaurant would be accommodating for this.

We were seated outside and we could tell that this wasn't going to be idea.  It was already cold (low to mid 40's) by the time our 9:30pm reservation was.  Outside, they had heating ducts above us with a single vent to each table/cubicle.  The issue is, you'd feed a burst of hot air every 10 minutes or so and then nothing, so there wasn't a constant source of heat to keep you warm.  In addition, there were no flaps or anything there to help keep the heat in.  We all know heat rises, so blowing hot air down, while outside on a breezy cold fall evening with no way of keeping the warm air inside, isn't going to work.

On to the food.  It was "OK".  I wouldn't write home about it and I wouldn't come back for it, so I was shocked that the reviews were overwhelmingly positive.  We definitely didn't have that experience.  

We asked our server about the cheese tasting platters.  We were a party of 3 and she said there'd be no problem and have "plenty" of cheese for our party.  Well,  hate to differ but what we got wasn't enough for 3.  2, yes, but 3, no.  There wasn't even 3 pieces of the crustini cracker for 3 people.  There was a VERY small amount of a fig spread on an endive and another VERY small dab of balsamic vinegar on another piece of endive.  

Two of us had the gnocchi which were good.  The paccheri was decent, but I felt the portion was small.

Dessert was very awkward.  We ordered the gelato (again, what people rave about)... We had the chocolate strawberry which was good, and the cannoli flavored gelato (didn't taste like it to me).  Two of us finished while the third was finishing her gelato.  One of the busboys came by to clean the table and when we explained we were still eating, he stood there waiting for our friend to finish her last few bites of gelato.  We explained we "were still eating" and he took a few empty plates and left, only to come back a few minutes later to get the last gelato dish.

No one came back out to refill our water glasses.  The only time we saw the server was the obligatory check in on us after the meal was delivered and to bring the check.

We get it... The restaurant closes, you want to clean the tables and get everything cleaned up, but come on.

All in all, the experience was less than ideal and sadly, didn't experience the "amazing" experience that others did.

I toyed with the idea of a 2 star review because Gran Caffe is a very spacious and impeccably clean restaurant in a nice area of Philly with very good service but in good conscious I couldn't give them any more than 1 star for the food they subjected us to. Gran has a few levels (the front of the street level is their coffee shop and gelato counter). There's a good chance if you're just coming here for gelato or espresso that you may get something of quality but that certainly doesn't carry over to their food. The fact that their prices are as high as they are just put the nail on the coffin for my wife and I who both agreed our meal here was one of the worst we've ever had, anywhere. Top 3 bad in fact (probably top 1 for her). It's also worth mentioning that the place also just feels like a large chain restaurant right down to the uniforms, borderline costumes, that the wait staff is forced to wear. 

For drinks she ordered a $12 cocktail called Sgroppino (lemon sorbet, processco, lemoncino vodka, fresh mint). This ended up being an incredibly weak and disgustingly sweet drink that she couldn't finish. Most of the beers were $7-10 but some as low as $5 or as high as $14 for a 12oz Italian beer with a 5% abv. I went with a $5 Peroni. For a starter we ordered their arancini ($10). This came presented beautifully and the texture was right but we both agreed it tasted a bit like soap and there was something definitely off with them. 

For a meal I had the Pappardelle Al Ragu Aquilano ($16.50) which is a wide ribbon pasta with slow cooked pork, veal, lamb, and chicken in a tomato based sauce. The meat had been pulverized to the point where it wasn't recognizable and the sauce was the worst tomato sauce I've ever had. It was the same tomato sauce that the aranacini came on and tasted like it came right out of a can of Ragu from the super market. I've had a lot of red sauce over the years and I don't hesitate to say that this was the worst and most store bought tasting I've ever had at a restaurant before. It was so disappointing that I have no doubt that I could have had a better plate of pasta from Olive Garden. 

As disappointing as my meal was, it was still edible which is more than I can say about my wife's dish. I felt so bad for her that I traded plates with her and couldn't even muster a second bite of her food after tasting it. To this day we both feel like gagging thinking about her dish and joke about how bad it was. She ordered the Agnoletti Al Tartufo ($19) which was ravioli stuffed with veal, pork, onion & herbs, topped with a butter-sage sauce and a little block of the chef's truffle gelato creation. The waitress assured us that the gelato wouldn't actually cool down the dish at all and would just melt over the dish infusing an extra flavor to it. Well this pretentious little gimmick did in fact cool down the entire dish to barely over room temperature and what it added to the dish was a disgusting overpowering truffle flavor that even a truffle lover like my wife couldn't stand. The ravioli's filling wasn't meaty either which was a big draw to the veal and pork stuffing. The mushy filling paired with this incredibly overpowered truffle flavoring, lowered temperature, butter sauce, and mediocre noodles just made this meal completely inedible. 

I've never been so disappointed not only in a restaurant but in Yelp's overwhelming praise for such a horrible Italian restaurant. Shame on you all for not knowing what good Italian food should taste like.

UPDATE:
I received one of the least professional business responses to this review where the manager Darren writes in part: "I believe the problem is that you have been subjected to so much Olive Garden style food over the years, that YOU in fact don't know what true, authentic Italian flavor is supposed to be."

Instead of engaging this guy privately I figured I'd just respond here. First of all I've only eaten at Olive Garden once in my life. 

Secondly, as far as my track record goes, with over 2,150 reviews on Yelp, only about 1% of those reviews are for 1 star so you can see I very rarely slam a place for being bad. Of those 23 one star reviews, only 8 of them are to food related businesses and half of those places have since gone out of business. About 40% of the restaurant's I've written 2 star reviews for have also gone under which is a stark difference from only about 12% of the restaurants I've written 5 star reviews for. With nearly 1,000 restaurant reviews and living not only in a mostly Italian neighborhood in Brooklyn but the area of the country with the most Italian-Americans and Italian restaurants I've eaten at more than my fair share of high quality Italian restaurants. 

Thirdly and most importantly when I visited, it was only 2 months after coming back from my two week honeymoon in Italy where my wife and I traveled all around the country searching out the best food possible. My taste in Italian food is clearly not the problem here.

So this is my once every 5 year best friend argument.  You know, that argument you have with your best friend every few years that makes you wonder why you're friends in the first place.  Then a week or so goes by and you realize it's only natural, and it's OK not to see eye to eye on everything!  I forgive you Yelp and I'm not going to throw away years of loyal friendship because you were dead WRONG about this place.  First off, we were asked if we had reservations for lunch in a restaurant that was half empty.  The outside dining area was 80% empty and we were seated there within a few minutes.  Water was brought to the table immediately, but we waited for at least 5 minutes for a waiter to even greet us.  And by greet I mean, come over and ask if we were ready to order when we didn't even have menus yet.  He didn't introduce himself, mention any specials or crack a smile. (under a mask that was half off his face)

We ordered a prosciutto plate which was fairly dry with some wilted greens.  I had the spaghetti carbonara which was fine, nothing special and a ricotta cheesecake which was OK too.  I don't remember anything much about the meal except I ate it with little interest other than hunger and I was paying for it.  The prices were extremely high for the quality, but the kicker was the poor service.  I think our waiter checked on us once, until I had to call him for the check.  But wait, there's more!  As he walked away and saw I only tipped 15%, I saw him shaking his head and say, "come on people". The effing nerve! 

Now remember, I tipped 15% because it's the decent thing to do.  Even if I get bad service, I still tip 15%, I just won't go back to that establishment.  I normally tip 20% for good service and  25% for excellent service.  I did this even before Corona because people are working hard for their money, most times.  His entitlement was the only thing that shined during the encounter and that was proven by his reaction to a standard tip.  I have no sympathy for people who dial it in at work, put no effort and expect optimal results.  All this coupled with mediocre food qualifies for a 2 star rating. I understand I'm an outlier here, but it was what it was.

For a coffeeshop, the tables are pretty spaced apart which makes it a great place to get some work done without being distracted by other people's (sometimes obnoxiously loud) conversations going on on the side. The place is well-lit with good ambience.

That being said, depending on who's working, the music can be way too loud. Also, the tea selection is okay but not extensive, though the london fog is pretty good. I wouldn't say anything here is worth paying 4-5 bucks, which is how much most beverages seem to cost. I really only come here when I  want a change of pace while still being productive. There are definitely better places to go if you're looking for a quality drink.

Shady Business
They overcharge here so ask for a receipt. 
I ordered a small chickpea salad (menu: $3.50) and a soy chai latte ($5.00) and was charged $10.95. Listen, I'm no math wizard but that just doesn't add up. I usually trust the person behind the counter (mistake?) so I initially paid the $10.95 without hesitation then quickly realized that I am not in NYC (where $10.95 for a small tupperware of chickpeas and a small latte is not ok but is the norm) so I checked the menu. When I confronted the barista about the odd math, she was like, "nope! $10.95"
And she wouldn't give me a receipt. 

Though the experience left a bitter taste in my mouth, the tiny chickpea salad was actually pretty good. The soy chai latte was room temperature and the flavor left much to be desired.

Finally, the new Square One Coffee shop is open. I have to walk pass everyday so why not stop in for a cup. Upon entering, I had to take my shades off, but even then, it was WAY too dark in there. Not ambiance mind you, just not enough light (natural or otherwise). The noise level was off the charts, a group of old dudes in the corner really messed me up. I wanted to sit and enjoy my java, but they were so loud! Sitting outside was a no go, the proverbial trash truck that picks up from the flop house on the corner was parked out front and the stench was unbearable. I had to cross the street and cross back just to get there (to avoid my clothes smelling like hot garbage). Dudes were in there with laptops, so I'm guessing they have wi-fi. Anyway, the clean, mod and sleek interior was cool, seating arraigned around the perimeter of the store and the smell was heavenly. I don't know the lay of the land yet, so I  kept it simple and ordered a medium cup of coffee. The girl at the counter was very helpful and greeted me warmly (#win) and served up my cup lickity split. The 'fixin's' bar was around the other side of the island. they only had 1/2 and 1/2 , no skim milk, whole milk or soy (#nonwin) out for use. They had the blue and yellow stuff as well as that brown sugar and white sugar. No stevia (yet - fingers crossed) to speak of. There is really only room for 1 person at a time to doctor up their drinks with a tiny trash hole on the left side.  

All in all, not bad. A medium coffee is $2.25 (*bucks prices) They have $1 refills (at least that's what I thought I read), some pastries but nothing appetizing (It's still early, I know). I'll visit again for sure, but I'll make sure the block is trash truck free and the gang isn't inhabiting.  It's so close to my job, I'd love to make it my 'spot' to get away.

Delicious coffee - check!
Free seltzer water at the perfect temperature - bonus!
Friendly barista who welcomed me - yes!

Can we talk about the meticulous planning that was required to purify the water and then replace the minerals they wanted to add to make their water, and therefore coffee, EXACTLY the way they thought it should taste?  I agree with their palettes, it is amazing and refreshing.  I can't wait to come back when it isn't a hundred degrees outside so I can enjoy their hot brews.

I don't know what everyone is complaining about with the ambiance.  It is minimalist, sure, but inviting and open.  Light wood, chevron white subway tile, and the bar is in the the middle.  It could probably use a few larger tables, but maybe the small tables were chosen on purpose to discourage loud, large groups?

The floor is painted concrete, so no noise absorbing material.  The music was an appropriate volume (maybe a touch loud, but I think most people listen to their music a bit loud) and tasteful.

I have appreciated Square One beans since I discovered them, and will make the trek out of my neighborhood to come here when I can.

5 stars for the location and surrounding neighborhood (gayborhood!) 

2 stars for the coffee, service 

1 star for the price ($3 for a 16 oz iced coffee that the barista filled up to 3/4 of the cup...no) 

I came around 4 pm on a weekday. I was the only customer in line and both baristas for some reason made me wait a good couple of minutes before they noticed me standing at the cashier. I respect that hipster culture comes with an inherent sense of aloofness/ quirkiness that I might not understand, but if it comes at the expense of customer service... then that is a questionable business model. 

I took my iced coffee outside and had a pleasant stroll down 13th street. The surrounding neighborhood is very picturesque and instagrammable. See my photo upload!

I really want to like this place. It looks great and it's so close to my apartment that it would be so amazing if I loved it but sadly I just don't. After moving in close by I started stopping by on my way to work. The coffee must just not be for me, it always seems very bitter to me and I always need to add creamer once I get to work(I usually just add a splash of skim milk). Also the staff is never that friendly when I'm in there and a few times I would be waiting at the counter for some time while they would be talking to each other. Once they would wait on me they would seem annoyed that they had to. There is one girl that is very friendly that I saw on my last visit there and she even offered me a frequent buyer card. Sadly with so many coffee shops on my walk to work I'll be choosing another from now on.

Hop off the 12/13th Locust line and stop into Square One Coffee. Easily one of my favorite places to get work (or creative work) done. The coffee... rivals La Colombe. That's a bold statement. I don't know if it has something to do with the oat milk (love Oatly, the new milk that is cropping up in all notable shops) or what, but their iced coffee is always one of my top choices. The prices are extremely competitive. $2.50 for an iced coffee or hot coffee. It's rare that you find the two with a similar price tag. The food choices are minimal, but they offer a selection of local baked goods. I finally tried an everything bagel. Although a little doughy (unsure who the purveyor was), it was toasted perfectly and topped with a bean-free sweet potato hummus... that wasn't even on the menu yet. The barista, who always greets me with a warm welcome, was kind enough to let me try it out since I ordered the Sabra hummus anyway. Pro-tip: always go for the house-made stuff! Anyway, love this place. Always leaves me satisfied. Recommend this location over JFK.

I walked by their store front when it was still under construction and when I looked in, I saw a beautiful La Marzocco espresso machine next to white tiles and blonde wood.  It immediately jumped to the top of my list of things to try.  Square One has a pretty strong reputation in Lancaster from what I've seen on the internet, which increased my excitement level.  

I tried a cappuccino, which was priced at 3.25; spot on.  The foam was well done, but the art was a little lacking.  The drink itself had a strong bite to it initially, but further down, the taste became more sweet, however, not in an unpleasant, artificial way.  It was reminiscent of something fruity. That sweetness is something that seems original to Square One's espresso.  In my experience, aftertastes in cappuccinos are usually bland (slightly milky), or sour.  

I liked the product here and my experience definitely verged on five stars.  I think there are still kinks to work out.  The space is big, but with limited seating, which could be a good or bad thing depending on your preferences.  There wasn't a buzz yet, but I'm sure there will be as time passes.  Square One's product is definitely worthy of one.

Came down the street from Green Eggs bc the wait was going to be about 40 mins.  When looking places up, I saw some nice latte art pics from here.  Thought this place would be nice to grab a quick drink and chill instead of on the sunny street with the rest of the Green Eggs mob.  Quite wrong.

I will say that the environment is a really pleasant one.  Wonderful natural lighting and nice seating.  It's pleasing to the eye, so I can imagine it'd be a nice place to get some work done.  While it would've been more enjoyable to relish in under better circumstances, at least it made the long wait for the drinks slightly more relaxing.

We waited 20 mins for two drinks.  We noticed that people who ordered after us were getting all of their orders. Finally my bf checked in on it and the guy completely forgot... That's cool. -_- So then of course he rushed making the drinks.  Another reason why I like sitting inside to enjoy my drink is bc as a stereotypical asian girl, I like to eat with my eyeballs and take pictures.  However, instead of getting my latte in a mug with some nice frothy art, it was thrown into a to go cup, plain as ever.  Sighs.

I would've at least been happy if the latte were well made.  But again, either the guy rushed thru it, or it's just not very flavorful at baseline.  Regardless, I wasn't too happy with it.  Oh wells, you win some, you lose some.

Square One Coffee is a hipster coffee joint that has a lot of comfortable and eclectic seating (they have a couch!), good wifi and its a big open space. It has pleasent decor and big windows with natural light. Its a great place to do some work and youll find many people doing exactly that. The coffee was good and you get a free refill if you have it there! (subsequent ones are a dollar!). Food was good but nothing spectacular. 

Now for the FAPS breakdown:

Food Quality - Only had some snacks and coffee so i cant confidently say too much about the quality of the food. It looked good though. The coffee was pretty good and Im sure many hipsters would be proud of their product. 

Ambiance - Its a big room with an HQ type area in the middle where you go up to order. All around there is a variety of seating and tables. The chairs are pretty comfortable and tehy even have some couches if youre looking to just kick back and have a nice warm beverage. They usually have some nice coffee music in the background. Theres a lack of outlets which is their downfall. 

Price - $$ - its what you would expect for a hipster coffee joint. 

Service - Everyone was pleasant and more than happy to help you with whatever you needed. Place was clean and chique.

First time here. NOT IMPRESSED AND ANGRY. I went in to get a good cup of coffee and before I could even finish ordering the barista was rudely correcting my vocabulary about the coffee. I ordered a pour over, paid, and sat down. Another barista came over to me a moment later and said he had not rung me up, I insisted I had already paid. He said I had not. I walked over to the counter with him, pulled out my change and receipt and he was still arguing with me. I had to get the attention of the lady who rang me up so that she could come verify that I had paid. EXTREMELY RUDE.

I really appreciate a coffee shop that makes you feel productive/creative as soon as you walk in the door. A big part of the reason I go to local coffee shops is to feel inspired by the environment. The inside was has simple, yet thoughtful, light/airy decor with quality local art for sale around the perimeter. The coffee bar/cash register is centrally located with seating (both private tables and larger community tables) surrounding the cafe. The music was upbeat, contemporary, and at the perfect volume as to not be a nuisance while writing or conversing.

I was greeted by a friendly barista who cared that I was there. I wanted to try the local, Lancaster roasted coffee, so she recommended, and offered a sample of the special drip coffee they were serving. It was excellent; very mellow, low acidity, and slightly nutty. However, I wanted to try one of the more premium pour-overs and decided on the single-origin, Colombia. It was so easy to drink, very balanced, fruity and nutty at the same time and really smooth.

My only qualm (hence the 4 star review) was that the coffee was served in a relatively thin, glass carafe. I wanted to leisurely sip and enjoy the coffee, not rush in fear that it'd be cold soon. Unfortunately, by the last pour, it was quite cold and unenjoyable. The first three mugfuls were great, though. For a $6 specialty pour-over, I just hoped to enjoy every last drop. 

When I return to visit Philly, I'll definitely come back to Square One Coffee and will recommend it to anyone looking for a great place to caffeinate and chill. Next time I'll most likely order the drip coffee or espresso so I can enjoy it from start to finish.

I really love this cute, comfortable and quiet coffee shop which to me feels somewhat like a bookstore with the comfy couches, wooden tables and chairs, it's quite refreshing to actually be able to hear yourself think rather than the typical frantic coffeehouse buzzing alive at many busier establishments. I am a dog walker in the area so for me, it's nice to have a clean, quiet and friendly coffee shop to get something replenishing to drink like their delicious iced teas!  I've tried both the berry, a fruity one and the apple berry which was more cinnamon like, they're both great and not sweetened so I added some Splenda, my fave!  I've also tried some of the tasty treats and the sourdough bread toasted with jam was really delicious!  I also really enjoyed the nutty chocolate chip bread!  

There's plenty of Wi-Fi, outdoor seating, clean bathrooms, a nice upbeat jazzy music playing, overall this place has a great laidback and relaxing vibe!  Great to be able to fill up my water bottle with either sparkling water or fresh, how nice, especially for someone like myself who is constantly out in the summer heat as a dog walker.  I'm still rather new to this fun place as I don't come everyday because I live a few blocks away, but when I do, I really enjoy it, I can relax and next time, I'll bring my knitting or a book!  A very nice, classy, more upscale coffee shop in my view than the everyday coffee shop and I really enjoy it here!!  Hip to be square!!!

Philly's coffee obsession continues with the recent opening of Square One Coffee out of Lancaster County - and I'm not complaining! My husband and I were taking a leisurely Sunday stroll when the heat made us both crave some cool respite. I remembered that Square One Coffee had just opened near where we were, so I led him into their sizable space on 13th Street.

The place feels HUGE when you walk in. Lots of light colored wood, and the bright sunlight filled the one room. The counter is towards the back, and the front has a bunch of small tables and chairs - no table could hold more than 3 people, and it would be slightly cramped, not sure why they didn't want to add a few larger tables to fill the space and make it seem less...empty and lonely. The two quiet staffers were nice and answered our few questions, pointing out their few baked goods (not made on premises, but a local bakery nonetheless). We both went with their cold brew, which was delicious and smooth (should've asked for less ice though). Prices are on par with the other counter culture coffee establishments in Philly, so slightly pricey. But you can also buy bags of their different roasts to make your own at home! Tea is there, too, for the non-coffee drinkers.

The quality of this store has drastically gone down in the last few months. I'm not sure if the management has changed for the worst or if their practices have changed but this is far from an improvement. The manager is not available whenever needed, staff seem distressed and overworked. I've spent years working as a barista and this store's quality and operations do not match up. 

Coffee recently tastes burnt or over extracted. The new baked goods have a lackluster taste, they look very appetizing but there isn't any flavor. Although I should add that their vegan pulled pork wraps tasted stellar and clearly came from a different place. If they were homemade I wouldn't be surprised because that seems to be the only food that had any effort invested in it. 

It's a shame because the location is perfectly nestled in the Gayborhood, and the atmosphere is aesthetically pleasing. But their presentation drastically clashes with their current execution. I don't know what has changed, or what will change, but I won't be returning.

Came here primarily because it was pretty empty while other area shops were much busier, which should have tipped me off. On that note, there is lots of space, so if you are looking for a place to meet, study, or work and don't so much mind what you are drinking then this is your place!

In terms of the coffee, this is where they really fell flat. I went to the register and ordered a cortado for here. The person at the register yelled 'can I get a Gibraltar, piccolo, flat white, cortado or whatever its called?' to the barista. My expectations of what I would then drink fell way down from that point forward as she had just named three distinctly different drinks and a piece of glassware. 

Once the drink was made it turned out to be a cappuccino in a paper cup that tasted over extracted and burnt. So, if you're keeping track, the shot and/or the beans were bad, they didn't make it in a cup to stay, and they gave me a different drink than I had ordered. All around, not so great. Maybe I just came on an off day.

Really underwhelmed by this coffee shop. It looks great from the outside and the inside is spacious and probably a great space to get work done while enjoying coffee. However, the menu that they display is limited. I asked for iced coffee and the cashier looked at me like I had 6 heads and should've assumed...but that wasn't on the menu. Aside from some pastries, they have bagels - but just bagels. And various toppings and spreads. Of the 3 bagel options, I picked a sesame bagel and asked for cream cheese initially. Later, I went back and asked for a a different spread and they said no because they all had various prices. Well- there are no prices listed for anything on the food menu, so I had no idea. The biggest pitfall here, though, is that the "large" size iced drink is about 16 oz - roughly the size of a grande at Starbucks for reference. And not filled all the way up. I can only imagine what a small is... there are so many great coffee shops in the area so I think I will stick to those and skip this place in the future.

I really wanted to like this place. The space is bright, inviting, and conducive to productivity, and I was digging the overall atmosphere as soon as I walked in.

What I wasn't digging, though, was my latte. I'm used to my suburban coffee shop whipping up a smooth, silky oat milk latte each and every time. Literally, my only complaint is that it once arrived too hot.

The latte I received here made me miss my neighborhood oasis. Square One's latte was bitter, because the coffee was bitter. I noticed that the barista used Pacific brand oat milk. Not Oatly, but the next best thing, and what my local place uses. This bitter latte also cost me $6.50. Ouch!

I don't think I'd return here for any reason. There are too many coffee options close by, and I have a feeling plenty of them have perfected the latte.

Long before entering the cafe Square One was a coffee roaster I knew about from selling enticing beans like their Ethiopian, Costa Rican, and House Blend at Wholes Foods.
