Not even CLOSE to what I ordered. I also ordered a spicy philly panini that was also supposed to be on ciabatta bread, and it came on soggy regular bread as well. So not only was one order wrong, both were wrong. I am extremely disappointed as the food looks nothing like how it is described or pictured. I do not recommend this place. UPDATE: They have messaged me and said they will give me a refund which is nice.

Yummy! Came here based on the great Yelp reviews and was not disappointed at all!
There's a huge selection of Paninis, wraps, salads, smoothies and morning bites like bagels.

I went for the "incredible lox", a bagel with lox, cream cheese, avocado, tomato and fried egg for $9.75. The prices are low, this is basically the most expensive item on the menu!
Unfortunately, they were out of bagels, but suggested the multigrain bread to go with it, which was a solid choice.

I also got a maple latte with almond milk. The maple flavor is a little subtle, but still enjoyable.

My favorite is the sandwich, which is loaded with lox and the other ingredients. All fresh and delicious.

There's various seating areas from high tables along the windows to a comfortable padded bench and low tables with chairs.

I will recommend this place to my fellow conference folx and would come again happily.

The menu is on the wall and you go up to the counter to order.  Nice selection of items, such as wraps, lox, eggs and avocado toast, very reasonable prices. We then sat down at one of the few tables to wait for our orders.  The table, the floor, the windows, the napkin holders all looked like they hadn't been cleaned or wiped in years. We had already ordered the food so we stayed, but the atmosphere was a major turn off. When the food came after a long wait it was all actually very good. But because of how dirty the place is I would never recommend it.

While the food is decent, I have to mention the absolutely terrible customer service. I ordered a meal and latte (with oat milk, vanilla, and Iced- so it was $7) for pick up. My mom picked up my order for me and she asked "is this everything?" And they said yes. They didn't give her the iced latte or even make it yet. I called the store once my mom got home and there was no latte. They said they couldn't give me a refund because I ordered online and they aren't associated with that platform. I was confused and asked why I would have to pay for something I didn't receive. They said there was absolutely nothing they could do for me besides making me a new one if I came back. I was already home and told them I just wanted a refund but they couldn't do that for me. Very disappointing because the food wasn't half bad (also wasn't great either).

I've been looking for an all-purpose eatery for a while, and I think I've found it in Cafe Square One. Salads, sandwiches, and even sushi are available, plus a few snacks and pastries. La Colombe coffee and smoothies are served, too.

All of the food I've had is good here--the sushi is very fresh and the sandwiches are all made to order. Definitely try the SQ Melt--it's a loaded three-cheese grilled cheese with tomato, avocado, and bacon. Plus it's only $6.75, which is a low price for an Old City sandwich.

Free Wifi is an added bonus, and there is a surprisingly large amount of seating for such a small place. However, the bathroom is out of order indefinitely, so you won't be able to sit here and drink coffee all day.

My biggest complaint is that the menu in store is a little confusing--the sandwiches are listed with their base price, which is good, but some of the extra ingredients (like a fried egg on the Baconator) is misleadingly listed as being part of the sandwich, when one actually has to ask to add it on, for an extra price. Some clarification would be helpful.

Was very excited to come here because my friend loves this place. The atmosphere is nice and my friend had great things to say about the owner Ross. Unfortunately he was not working when I went and my service experience was subpar. Told the barista it was my first time there and she did not try to explain the menu to me. The way they make their coffee is very interesting and the owners' dedication to their craft is clear from their website and social media, but I learned more from their website and my friend than I did in the coffee shop itself. I am not a coffee connoisseur so I am pretty easy to please, but I felt rushed to order though there was no line and the barista looked at me like I was stupid when I asked questions. The way they lay out their menu with describing what the "tasting notes" are for each coffee is cool but can be confusing without an explanation. The coffee I got was decent- goes down smoothly and has a sweet aftertaste- but I ordered it more because the barista told me it was the only iced coffee they were serving at the time and I didn't have much time to look at what the other options were. It seems like a nice coffee shop and I think my experience was definitely tainted by the poor service, but I would not go out of my way to come here again.

Knowledgeable & Ross: the two words I would use to describe FCL.

Why? Because Ross is the knowledgable mastermind behind FCL. His passion, joy, and creativity with knowledge on coffee highlighted my experience. Looking at a menu can be overwhelming and oddly confusing, especially when you're no coffee expert on certain types of beans and the brewing process [aka me.] 
Ross delights in educating the customers and picking the right cup of joe for each individual- perfect duo. The menu changes, but what I can say is that the texture of the coffee goes down very smoothly- which is hard to find. However I didn't taste what the description of the coffee said it would, such as grapefruit or pb ice cream. The taste was rather subtle. Although I did appreciate that the taste was brewed well, and not overpowering or burnt. 

Conclusion? 
Honestly speaking, I probably liked Ross and picking at his knowledgeable mind more than my cup of latte- not because I didn't like my lattes, but because Ross is that awesome to meet and learn from.

Function Coffee Labs is amazing. Ross gracefully combines the welcoming hospitality of a local independent coffee shop and the creative, fun, nerdiness of a great, 3rd wave, speciality coffee shop. 

My common experience at most 3rd wavey coffee spots in Philadelphia leave me cold and have "forgot the plot" (as Gordon Ramsay says) - a sense of forgetting to fill the space with good spirit, warm welcoming and goodness in people, as is the essential component to food service/ hospitality. 

My experience here is that guests connect with each other BECAUSE Ross shares his passion with lightheartedness, joy, and intentional accessibility. He sets the tone.

What Ross offers in terms of hospitality, and coffee goodness, is both rare and lovely. You don't need to "get it" to appreciate what he is doing here. The love in it is obvious. If you are coffee nerd you might set up a yurt in the neighboring park. 

Rumi says,"Your task is not to seek for love, but merely to seek and find all the barriers within yourself that you have built against it." Ross is a person who loves both people and coffee freely. His heart & care are obvious.

coffee is decent at best-- sad excuse for a pastry selection. not sure how they got all of their bad reviews (there were 20+) deleted about the fact that get fired a transgender employee that was being harassed by customers and had reached out for support. this review is not about that though (even though it is very shady) it's about the lackluster overpriced coffee that they try to pass off as "science"

Function is a wonderful coffeeshop, with an exceptionally knowledgeable owner and an always interesting array of coffees. Ross is very friendly and loves to talk about coffee and brewing methods, and has a very discerning palate. The other baristas are also very friendly, and I have yet to have a cappuccino, pour-over, or espresso that wasn't excellent. 
However, Function does have one not-insignificant drawback, and that is the pastries. Given the quality of coffee, my expectations were high, especially since many Philly cafes have pretty good pastries. Unfortunately, most of the pastries at Function however are not worthy of the coffee they are served with. They tend to be dry, overcooked, too sweet, or bland. There are certainly exceptions like the cheesecake and hand pies, which are both very good! 
The space isn't huge, but is very pleasant, the wifi is excellent, and there are chairs and tables outside in nice weather which is great!
The Brazil espresso I had was not good, poor crema, thin and over extracted if I had to guess I would say the grind was too coarse
Awful!!! Never going back there ! The coffee wasn't even hot like I asked and plus I heard about the transgender that got fired and that's to ok at all . Never going back !!

Couple notes on this place:
1. Overpriced - 5.75 for a small chai latte with almond milk?!
2. Minimal flavor options: no vanilla, only maple or honey. 
3. Minimal sweetener options: only simple syrup. 
4. Poor pastry selection.
5. Overnight oats: overpriced and bland... the ones I make at home are better.
6. Very small location - not much parking or seating.

Function Coffee Labs has the friendly coffee craft game on lock. I live in a city that attracts coffee enthusiasts from across the country, and I'd trade all of Portland's award-winning specialty roasters and retailers for easier access to a café like this.
 
Take 60 seconds to scan the menu overhead and there will be no need to read between the lines: Function Coffee Labs is out to save you from so much as a sip from a subpar cup. This is very, very good coffee. Meticulously sourced, small-batch, artisanal; you could rattle off all the makings of a third wave coffee shop too. But it's not just the espresso (or the coffee shot, or the cortado, or the cappuccino -- oh my god, the cappuccino) that makes me wish FCL were a fixture on my own walk to work.
 
-Service: Chances are, the owner will be the one behind the bar. Here's what I liked about Ross: he's able to read people. If Instagram is your thing, you can count on a latte that looks too good to drink. If you want to talk about the latest signature drink and grams and fluid ounces and what he's tweaked to dial it in that day, he will happily oblige. It doesn't matter whether you've ordered the same drink for the past decade or if 90% of your counter space is devoted to home brewing gadgets and accessories. There's nobody more down-to-earth, knowledgeable, or contagiously enthusiastic about temperature, technique, purveyors, and flavors. But if you just want your large iced coffee to go, ideally sooner rather than later (since you're running a few minutes behind), he'll hop to it. And in either case, he's bound to remember your name the next time you come in.
 
-Ambiance: 10/10. Perfect playlists. The happy hum of caffeinated (and soon-to-be caffeinated) people. Just the right amount of miscellaneous background noise. No shortage of green growing things. A variety of tables for slow-sipping, talking, reading, or working. This is the type of place where you can meet someone for a blind date, catch up with a friend, get good work done on your laptop, and/or easily befriend someone sitting a table away.
 
-Aesthetic (and other bonuses): Ross's fiancé and co-owner, Meg, is behind much of FCL's aesthetic appeal. The brightly lit, smartly branded shop has a clear color palette, with broad navy strokes and splashes of white. Copper elements abound, as do pretty pops of turquoise. A chalkboard sign out front speaks to Ross and Meg's combined intelligence and wit; the creative commentary is often as social media worthy as any pourover action shot. The real draw, however, may be the bakery case, which is loaded with the homey and locally sourced, each more irresistible than the next. If none of the day's sweet treats sway you, snack options range from Stroopwafels and bean-to-bar chocolates to RX bars and overnight oats. If you're lucky enough to get your hands on one of the half dozen breakfast sandwiches the café puts out each morning, don't tell me. You'll break my heart.
 
All this to say, if you're lucky enough to have Function Coffee Labs at your fingertips: Go hungry. Go thirsty. And go now, before the place shoots to the top of the standing-room-only list. This is specialty coffee done right.

Not only was Function Coffee Labs not FUNCTIONAL they were rude. We had two separate to go cups of coffee where the lids came off spilling coffee everywhere. 
In addition to lids that didn't fit the cups, they advertised a tasting and then acted like we were crazy when we asked about it. Plus the coffee sucked.

Given all the great reviews, I was excited to try this place out. I stopped in and ordered an iced oat milk latte on a Sunday afternoon. It was past the busy time, so I was the only customer in the store. Not only was it a bit overpriced, but the gentleman handed my my drink with barely any ice, and tons of room in the top. It was about 90 degrees outside (August heat wave) and I politely asked the barista to top off the ice. He did so begrudgingly after clearly making a face. All of this would have still been okay-- if he put enough ice in the second time, which he did not. 3 minutes later, I had a watered down latte with no ice.

In fairness, the website does say that they prefer you to come and place your order at the door. Because I have three compressed fractures in my back, we ordered online and were told our order was ready five minutes later. As we live just a few blocks away, that worked for us. When we arrived we went to the door and they started preparing our order. Luckily there were not many people there yet, so we were able to sit at a table outside. The upside of this was that we had the payment and tip processed online. 

My husband had an egg sandwich and while both the biscuit and eggs were prepared without salt and there was no salt available. He loved his house Americano. I had a cappuccino and a pastry. The fruit cream pastry had blueberries and they were beautifully tart - 10 stars!

I also ordered an artisan naturally leavened bread. Unfortunately, they don't slice it and anyone that eats this bread knows that it is difficult to cut. I enjoy a crispy crust on bread, but this was so overly cooked, I might even say burnt. 

All in all, we enjoyed our Sunday morning breakfast. I will definitely go back. I took one star off for the burnt bread

Function Coffee Labs is one of those places that literally read into exactly what I needed to function on any given morning! But it also won me over because of incredible baked goods and cool South Philly mosaics.

Function is housed in a spot that to be another decent South Philly coffeehouse which had Isaiah Zagar style mosaics that always win me over. But as that coffeehouse went away I continued to see those wonderful mosaics stay in place but also continue to grow in placement and coffee phrasing. And upon the next visit I discovered a new house that offered siphoned coffees, unique bean varieties, and spot on recommendations. 

When Function became my regular on the way to work caffeine destination it also became my occasional breakfast nook. And function proves to be better than most other local cafes for it since it partners with local bakeries like Essen and Machine Shop for their flaky and decadent pastries, but also makes other good options like avocado toast and a breakfast sandwich that puts baked egg and cheese on a buttermilk biscuit. While I'm normally not a croissant person, its also pretty hard to resist the everything croissant with goat cheese and your favorite bagel spices, or the toasted ham & gruyere one.

the coffee can be a bit more pricier, but worth it for the quality, especially when you buy enough to get a free cup by using Square!

Is there something about being a "barista" that makes you as bitter as the coffee you are serving? I try to support local business as often as possible but this was not my first unpleasant experience in a "quaint" little coffee shop. This Saturday afternoon I decided to take a break from studying and venture over to Function Coffee Lab because their website mentioned that they carried Franklin Fountain ice cream and I had been really wanting to try it. Rather than going all the way to Old City, I was relieved to learn that I could get at least a couple of flavors nearby. 
When my husband and I walked in, we were greeted promptly, but when I mentioned that I was there to get some of this ice cream, it were as though I had three heads! There were a group of other employees having a conversation behind the counter and for them to have to pause their conversation and check in to this ice cream thing seemed like a major inconvenience. I was told by someone that they only keep it around to make a specific thing, but they could arrange to sell me some ice cream; it is listed on the menu, but somehow this idea was really off the wall! 
To sum it up, it was UNCOMFORTABLE; we could not wait to get out of there! As a person who has spent over 20 years in the service industry, I am very sensitive to the atmosphere of an establishment and this was not at all welcoming. Here's a tip--don't make people feel like they are a burden for patronizing your establishment!

Judging from their yelp page, Function Coffee Labs doesn't need another 5 star review. Alas, here we are!

I've only been here once, but I am in love. Came down here one morning to explore the Italian market and wanted to stop by for some coffee / breakfast. Their Sourdough Cinnamon Roll is amazing! I split it with my friend (the perfect amount of roll!) alongside a Rosemary molasses latte and was in heaven. The cinnamon roll was soft and pillow-y with the perfect not-too-too-sweet icing on top. The slight tanginess from the sourdough was amazing.

Also, the staff / setup here is great. You order inside and then wait outside for pickup by the window. There are a few tables set up outside which is super nice. Also the gentleman who took our order checked up on us a few times (but not in an annoying way) - very helpfully offering to take our trash which was at risk for blowing away or to offer a napkin when I smeared icing on my face (lol). 

Would wholeheartedly recommend this place, which is probably my favorite coffee shop in Philly! Can't wait to come back again.

Cute and bright little coffee place. They make a beautiful latte but their coffee tastes like there are grounds in it. I had overnight peanut butter which was delicious but my boyfriend had the breakfast sandwich was was very dry and lacking. There is wifi and some seating avaliable.

I originally wanted to order a vanilla latte here but they do not have vanilla flavor shots here which I thought was odd, but not a dealbreaker.  So I settled with a regular latte with no flavor shots and was not impressed. I am not sure what went wrong but my latte tasted like all milk/foam and no espresso.  I had high expectations for this coffee shop since the reviews are so good... maybe the barista was new and it was a one time mess up? Or maybe they just don't put enough espresso shots in their lattes?  For $4.25 for a small hot latte, I expect it to be better.

This is a particularly snooty coffee spot. I say this right off the bat because if you consider yourself a coffee snob, you'll probably enjoy this place. Truly! The coffee is unique. 

But if you're like me: pretty easy-to-please, happy with a generic "small coffee" pretty much wherever you go.... I'd do a pass. 

No thanks, don't need a pour-over crafted with beans that passed through the intestinal track of a yak and then roasted over a monk's campfire flame in the hills of the Himalayas. And definitely don't want to hear you talk about it endlessly while I wait, either. 

I can respect the craft, but meh. Another Philly coffee shop that drips with the air of total superiority. Good internet though, will hand em that. Otherwise, pass.

Nommingnomad Approved! 

Oh how I love cute little coffee shops!  I'm surprised that I haven't been here before now. I went there on a Sunday to get a drink and get some work done. It is such a cute coffee shop with indoor and outdoor seating. And they have great WiFi! Score. 

It is right opposite a little park and it's great for people watching and spending some tome alone or with some friends. I went in and was greeted so nicely by the baristas there. I saw beet latte on the menu and I had to have it. So I ordered that and the barista went "Yesss! I'm so excited to make it. No one ever orders that." That made me pause but I was so happy that I made him happy, I went with it! 

I grabbed a table outside because it was beautiful out. My Beet latte was ready soon and it was as delicious as it was pretty. I was a happy camper. I spent a couple of hours there and I'll definitely be back to try more drinks! 

Great place. Great drinks. Nice people. Yes yes yes!

I really, really, really hate doing this but I CAN'T give Rocket 4 or 5 stars like I would like to!!

I moved to Fishtown back in August and this was one of the first places that caught my eye. I love the interior! Everything on the menu so far has been really good, and I like that it's vegan/vegetarian friendly. I love all their hot drink, esp their creative lattes, and their cold drink selection is awesome, too.

My only complaint is that the service, while not necessarily "rude", is kinda off-putting? It's hard to explain, but it always seems like placing an order is an inconvenience to the cashier. It's not the same person every time, either, so maybe it's just the mood/shtick they're going for??

Also, whether I'm the only one there or not, it almost always takes 5-10 minutes to get my drink. While not a big deal, it does prevent me from considering Rocket Cat as a morning stop before work: every "quick drop in" turns into a much longer visit. 

These have been problems consistently every time I've gone to Rocket Cat, alone or with my boyfriend. He actually really doesn't like it here because of the service, but I come back a lot because I love everything else, and it isn't so bad that I can't just deal. 

TLDR; The ambience and hot drinks are great. Service questionable and often slow, but not unbearable. Recommend for chill place to hang out.

"Rocket Cat! Rocket Cat! Is a niche! 
How many hipsters can resist?"

The answer to that? Just step inside. 

If you are a resident to the Fishtown/Kensington hood this will be one of your independent coffee shops of choice. Being one of the only out in this art revival scene of the Northeast part of Philly. There aren't any Starbucks or other coffee chains besides a Dunkin' here and there but if you want to be able to get free wifi and finish that report due this friday goodluck b/c this part of town lacks that besides the trendy Northern Liberties...

...but who really has five bucks for a cup of organic cat pooh coffee that is hand-washed by Virgin tears, then blessed by the Tibetan monks before being flown over seas by Nordic Gods flying flaming chariots being pulled by singing cranes? 

Rocket Cat is a nice middle ground for fair coffee in the middle of a sprawling neighborhood of artists, families tied in ethnicities of all nature. One of the key things I like about this part of town. It still holds to it's roots and if you look beyond the hate, thugs, and crime that hang around here, there is a beauty to this relic. Most of the neighbors, even some you wouldn't expect are friendly. 

Yes, Rocket Cat, may have some clientele that resemble some you've seen at Chapterhouse or the Green Line or Last Drop with their self-importance attitude but where there's fair trade coffee and vegan cookies; there's going to be some douchy people lining up. 

One of the great things about Rocket Cat is it's space. It's very wide and plenty of room to stretch out. No worries of tripping over someone's laptop charger or over-hearing obnoxious conversations of some really cool house party no one cares about. Plus you can sit at the counter, much like a bar and get up-close service. 

Most the baristas are friendly, especially if you get to know them. Just start a conversation and you're bound to get a decent response from them other then some places where you'll get...

"Uhhhh... I'm sorry but I only talk to people that look like American Apparel models and know everything David Byrne ever did" 

Sometimes you might wait awhile for service but it's still worth it and it adds to how this is truly an independent establishment and not some mass-transit machine chain like other coffee places. Just come in, chill, read a book, and take a deep breath of some Northeast Philly comfort.

When my boyfriend and I first moved to Philly and specifically Fishtown, we came to Rocket Cat first and we were drawn to it for some reason.  It's not hard to actually say the reason- the place itself is interested, unique and fun to look at.  I love the indoor plants and the fact that it seems very homegrown in there.  We would get coffees all the time from this place and I would even say we became fairly regular here.  Aside from them only taking cash (which became a huge drawback because we barely ever carry cash on us and had to actually think about this before we would go there), it was also very close to our place and we often walked or biked there in no time.  During the warm months it was delightful and we would sometimes sit outside or even sit inside and enjoy all the light that came through.  

Downside: aside from a really nice lady who worked there: Jarmal as I can remember, the rest of the staff was surprisingly off putting.  For such a nice place, I would expect the staff to be the same but everyone aside from previously mentioned Jarmal was not very friendly at all.  For some reason, and I hate to go straight to this, but I felt like since my boyfriend and I werent 'hipster' enough, we werent accepted nor good enough to be friendly to.  You as a reader dont know me very well but trust me when I tell you, I am EXTREMELY nice and friendly and all around jovial to people, especially service people behind the register/counter.  I am beyond appreciative of what they do for me and what they have to go through sometimes with rude customers so I make sure that I am always peachy keen to them.  Lets just say that the majority of the staff at Rocket Cat do not return this positivity to me and to really get down to the point; that's why my boyfriend and I havent returned in several months.

If Rocket Cat Cafe is reading this- if you put a smile on and be a little nicer and accommodating to your customers, or my HUGE pet peeve: when i say 'thank you', please say your welcome or at the very least acknowledge the kindness of your customers.

Stopped in Rocket Cat Cafe after a cycling class at the studio across the street and I'm so glad I did! When you first walk in, you'll get a sense of the relaxed atmosphere and hipster vibes - but not in a bad way at all. The interior of this cafe is absolutely amazing. All of the decorations, as well as the chairs at the little coffee bar, are super unique and antique-looking. There are some nice tables by the windows on the left side of the cafe that give you a nice view of the street which is perfect for people-watching. It was very relaxing and enjoyable to sit, read, and drink my coffee for a while.

One thing you'll be sure to notice at this cafe is that there are TONS of different drinks! They have all of the classic coffee drinks you'd expect to find in any cafe as well as some unique drink options. There is also a refrigerator in the middle of the cafe that has a lot of vegetarian and vegan food options including the vegan pumpkin whoopie pie - so delicious!

I was so excited that they had a Thai Style Latte on the menu (which comes iced) so I ordered it and it exceeded all of my expectations. Hands down the best Thai Style Latte I've ever had! I also got a piece of the lemon pound cake with icing (which most certainly cancelled out any calories I burned from my cycling class...whoops). It was really yummy and I could tell that it was homemade and freshly baked. 

On the real though, I am seriously considering coming back to get another Thai Style Latte even though I am rarely in this area. It was that good!! Rocket Cat Cafe gets 5/5 stars from me mostly because that latte was so perfect, but also for the awesome ambiance, friendly baristas, and the vegan options! I'd definitely recommend checking it out if you're in the area.

This is one of those times when I'm torn between three and four stars. If this review was taking place four years ago, I probably would've given the RC four stars. They've got fantastic bagels and pastries*. The place is cozy and offers free wi-fi. The coffee is good most of the time. The veggie cream cheese is delicious (I swear they make it from fresh veggies themselves). Drinking the Thai Iced Coffee results in a reaction that will pretty much rival your best childhood Christmas morning ever. 

So what keeps me from giving it four stars? 

The service. It drives me batty. Over the years, I've seen the staff go from okay to flat out terrible. They are super slow, which is sort of forgivable in the late afternoon/evening, a time I associate with unwinding, but not in the morning when my hunger pangs are strong enough to make me want to eat a rock. Or anything else I find strewn about on the sidewalk. And half the time, they seem confused about how to properly toast and prepare a bagel. Within the last year, I've sort of given up on the clueless kids and have resorted to ordering my bagel untoasted, cream cheese on the side, to fix at home myself. It's a lot faster (again, sometimes). 

Man, I just want to light a fire under some asses! I know they like to maintain a laid back, I'm-an-artist-and-I-just-don't-care image, but come on. Enough is enough. It isn't that difficult to handle a crowd and some coffee. Skills! Learn them! Please!

Also, I wish someone would make sure all the staffers knew how to properly serve coffee: no pulling a cup 'til the brew is finished! I don't like drinking the occasional cup of weak brown water! Ever! 

Despite the negative things I've mentioned thus far about Rocket Cat, it is a generally swell little coffee shop. My gripes probably will not stop me from utilizing their services. After all, it's just around the corner from my house and how can I pass that up? 

That said, I really want to be able to up the star count on this one. I still have faith in you, Rocket Cat. I welcome you to prove me wrong about my peeves sometime soon.


*If you're low on cash, I suggest the day old pastries. They're half price and just as delicious as same day ones. This is one of my favorite things about Rocket Cat because, well, I love a bargain about as much as I love pastries.

So here are the things I look for in a coffee shop: 
1. The basics: Wifi, reasonably priced, good quality coffee, bathroom, adequate lighting--RocketCat actually fails here. This place is dark and moody and the bathroom is sketchy. And the Wifi is INCREDIBLY slow. The coffee was good and reasonably priced. Very limited sugar/milk options at the DIY bar. 
2. Hours: This is a win for RocketCat--6:30-8pm M-F, and 7/8am-8pm on weekends.
3. Ample seating and tables large enough to be conducive to studying--Meh, RocketCat gets a mere passing grade here--I never have too much trouble getting a table, but there aren't many of a good enough size to study. 
4. Ample outlets: Fail. I think there is one, if you don't get a table near it, I hope your laptop has a decent battery-life. 
5. Decent free/no time limit parking in the vicinity: Fishtown rocks at free parking.
6. Reasonably priced, healthy food options: Menu was a redeeming feature--good food, reasonable prices. 
7. Free, communal water (really just a perk)--nope 
8. Friendly staff: NOPE. The girl behind the counter acted like I was trying to rip them off when I asked for a refill--because you have to get a mug to get the refills, and I had originally bought a large. Even when I told her that I didn't know and that I didn't mind if she only filled it up as much as a mug, she gave me a bunch of attitude. How was I supposed to know the rules?!? Scheesch.  Since moving to Fishtown, I've learned there are two kinds of hipsters--the very friendly, just into living cheaply, vintage stuff and organic everything (ie: those at Pizza Brain or Johnny Brenda's) OR the super judgmental, too-cool-to-be-friendly types. The latter is what you find working at RocketCat. 
9. Cleanliness: Meh. Its so dark and gloomy, it seems dirty. No one cleans the tables when people leave. The staff looked like they could use a shower too. 
10. No arctic temps from over-air-conditioning: It was still winter, and they still failed at this--too cool for adequate heating too. I remember leaving b/c I was freezing, which is the last thing I want when its also freezing outside--probably why I asked for that refill in the first place. 

The only way I'll go back here is if I REALLY need to study later than 5pm on a weekend. Sigh.

I love coming back home and finding places that I haven't been to before, cause that means that Philly is growing and that is the best news anyone can ask for. This place seemed extremely well established so I don't think it was new, but it was new to me which is always the important thing. The atmosphere was really cool, people scattered around, some chatting, some working on their Macs, others reading. Typical coffee shop vibe if its a good coffee shop, which it was. I especially like the bar. I am generally a sit at the bar guy, and if you wander into a place by yourself and want to stay, the bar is your home away from home. They had you your drink past the people at the bar, like a bar would, so it somehow feels more sociable. I said a few words to the couple my drink was passed through and it was great. I had a mocha which was kinda out of character but I had just got done crushing several cups of coffee at brunch but couldn't pass Rocket Cat up when I walked by. See you next time I'm in philly!

Was inside for about an hour with my girlfriend meeting the account for a meeting and I'll never come back.  Food was delicious, service was super super rude.  I'm seriously disturbed to read report after report here on yelp about how consistently rude the service is.

The two folks working at the bar had some sort of problem with...something that they never made known.  I ordered a sandwich that was "called out" that i didn't hear and had a super rude waitress who seemed to be ending her shift notify me pretty curtly that it was sitting there in a way that was more about me getting it off their counter than them being troubled about my not having it.

The young girl (all of the staff were youngish females) that cooked it made a serious effort to apologize that I hadn't gotten it in a timely fashion.  My girlfriend also noted that as soon as she came in and asked about ordering she got a 'long, blank, rude stare" from the lady manning (lol gender-pun) the counter.

It was like we did something wrong to them or were known dog abusers or vanadlizers or something, literally.  I got that vibe, like I was KNOWN for having done something bad in the community or something.  Sneers, rude curt snips.

Why would I pay money for people to treat me like this and wtf is going on in Fishtown where people are acting like this so much so that report after report says how mean these folks are. 

I left feeling like they wished I hadn't entered.  And I most likely never will again.  There are way too many places to sit chat, and eat in Philly.

I have been eating at Rocket Cat Café for many years, and also have contributed vegan baked goods to them.

This is one of the best independent coffee bars I have found in Philadelphia.  The waitstaffers are consistently courteous and polite without being overly friendly, and they treat patrons with more or less informality, as they wish.  Patrons vary from young parents with small children (children are welcomed here, and treated with respect and kindness), to young adults who are trying to save the world, to job interviewers and people working on laptops, to neighbors, to more mature patrons.  All are made welcome.  

The décor is modest, but welcoming and relaxing, and has a charm all its own.  The outside seating is charming as well.  The periodic displays are local art are appealing, as well.

The coffee is very good; the baked goods are very good; the bagels with veggie cream cheese are excellent; the everything bagels with veggie cream cheese, avocados, and extra tomatoes are top of the line.  The bowl of bite-sized chunks of raw sugar, near the coffee condiments, is a draw for patrons of any age.

I also have contributed vegan baked goods here.  These people are consistently pleasant to work with, have communicated everything clearly, and made my job as easy as possible.  The owner cares for her employees, and it shows.

A coffee bar, at its best, can be a kind of welcoming family room; and that is what patrons will find at Rocket Cat.

I'm still a little baffled with my experience here. I was warned it was cash only by a friend. I was also warned that the staff and patrons act a little different. Knowing it was cash only and I only had 1 100 dollar bill, I purposely padded my order to around 15 dollars so they could easily give me 4 20s back. Being a cash only place, I figured they would have plenty of change. I picked up a coffee cake, some juice, my friend's order and my coffee. Lady pours my coffee and comes back to the register.

I pull out my freshly minted 100 dollar bill and I got the most confusing response to money I have ever gotten in my life. 

"I'm sorry, but we don't accept 100 dollar bills." 

I was like.. what? You're cash only and I have cash.

"I'm sorry, but that's just our policy, you can get change across the street"

Lady points to two guys sitting on chairs outside of this ghetto ass car wash. 

"i reply back, no thanks, that's all I got"

Lady gives me look and goes here. I already poured the coffee, you can have it for free. 

"I said, thank you, you don't have too but I'll take it."

That's where I started thinking... This place just lost money by giving me that coffee for free because they wouldn't take my money.  I can deal with cash only.. I get it, like the rest of Philly you guys want to save on taxes. 

But if you're cash only, take my freaking cash. This is America, 100 dollar bills are part of the currency. I don't know if you're scared of fake bills, but your a coffee shop, who uses fake bills at a coffee shop??

I'm sorry, I just had to vent. I still can't believe they lost money because they wouldn't take my money. Unreal.

I love this place. I miss living in fishtown and going here regularly but it's a place I like to go between classes since Temple is just a quick bike ride away. I want to say lots of nice things about it. So let me get the one thing I don't like out of the way:

SOMETIMES I feel like I don't belong here. It's not that the employees are mean, I just have had a couple times (more in the past than recently) where I just didn't feel as welcome as a customer should. Either that or they just are having a grumpy day and didn't feel like cracking a smile or saying a "have a nice day." which happens to us all so I can look past it. but that's not all the time, and certainly not everyone who works here is like that so I do not want to generalize. 

so on to the good stuff!!!!!!!!!!!

when you walk up there's some outside seating and some really cool street art on the building. there's a good amount of seating inside (including a couch and some more relaxing chairs in addition to the pretty standard wooden ones), not to mention a charming little backyard. there's seating at the counter (which doesn't seem like a good place to get work done because everyone is always chatting it up so if you want some time to yourself, sit at a table in the corner). 

In addition to your regular coffee fare, there are baked goods (some vegan), juices, and a menu of pretty good food. I've only ever had their grilled cheese with avocado and I was a fan. It took sort of long to get my food, a little too long. but I think they were backed up or there was something holding up the process and they told me it would take a while in advance so it's not like I was kept waiting and not knowing what was going on. 

Rocket Cat also often has art openings on first fridays which are pretty cool and the vibe here is pretty good. I always see lots of awesome people.

Where to begin...

My girlfriend and I stopped in yesterday after the Trenton Ave Arts Fest looking for a refreshment and to use the bathroom on our way back to the el. Wow what a mistake. I suppose it all started after my girlfriend ordered a coffee and then asked me to grab it for her while she used the bathroom. So ok, yeah no problem. Few minutes goes by and I check back with her while she's waiting to use the the bathroom. I say "Hey, what did you order?" she replies "Just a coffee, why" I then remark "Oh ok, just making sure, guess they're brewing a new pot or something." As we finish up our conversation a patron who had been using the bathroom has now exited and she proceeds to enter the restroom. Only to be confronted with the stench and appeal of a ports-john after pointless fest (google it) that has been festering under the hot summer sun all damn week. And let me go on to say the two of us are not delicate or yuppies by any stretch of the imagination. With that said she let me know that she would just wait until we stopped somewhere else along the way. After that we both walked back up to the counter after finding the guy who she ordered from was just sitting down to eat a sandwich at the counter he had just prepared for himself. When I looked confusingly around for her coffee and then said "Hey, hows the coffee coming?" he looked up and said "Huh, oh I totally forgot" (oh did i mention the cafe was not busy and no one else had ordered before or after us) he then shuffles behind the counter and pours a cup from the first pot he comes to and hands it to us, with this disdained look like we had interrupted him, then headed back to his sandwich. After which we both look at each other and mutter. "Did that really just happen?" 

Needless to say we will not be returning anytime soon.

I have seen this place several times since I started going to another grocery store nearby and always wondered how it was.  I wandered in today, a very very nice day and got a cafe mocha and "angel" cookie(The server called it a conut(cookie/doughnut, and that was very appropriate). The cafe mocha was tasty as was the conut.  A welcome treat on a nice day.
     
     The decor is hard to explain. Its kind of arty/kind of old student house shabby but in a good way. An example is their bathrooms, which have what appears to be handpainted signs with "Onion" and "Garlic" on them. There is plenty of character as opposed to the sterile corporate interior design of Starbucks or some of the other chain stoors. The cafe has nice wood floors and plenty of seating. Decoration/paintings here and there. Lots of colors. Good music on the stereo, though today it was mostly "Juno"esque/grrrl rock(which the server was singing to. She wasn't half bad either).  There is a soda fountain type curved bar area where you can sit on stools which is kind of cool.
      As far as computing goes,Rocket Cat had an old Blue Mac G4 for you to check e-mail/stuff on the internet. It appears that they had wireless, though I didn't have my laptop with me so I can't confirm my suspicions. I also didn't see too many electric plugs so you'll have to forage around for one if you want to stay there for any length of time.

     The Cafe also had plenty of board games for you to while away your time. One little secret gem that I don't think the previous reviewers mentioned is that there is a small seating area in the back outside! Totally cool. I sat outside drinking coffee and smelling the flowers and listening to the birds chirp.  It felt like my own private park.

    The food looked pretty good but I didn't have any. I'll have to come back and try some out.

I agree with a lot of the people who have reviewed Rocket Cat.  I want to like it, but time after time I feel let down.  Today I met some friends there and although we were having a great conversation, we had to leave after 45 minutes because it was stifling and humid inside the cafe.  There were ceiling fans, but they do little when it is already 95 degrees.  I thought maybe the AC was broken, but looked around and didn't see any vents or units, so I assume it doesn't exist.  Sure, it can be considered a luxury, but not in an establishment where you are expected to spend any extended period of time.  

The service can be slow and if you don't know the drill there you can end up feeling like you don't belong.  One time, after ordering and waiting for my drink, I tried to pay at the far end of the bar instead of near the cash register because a new crowd had gathered and was blocking the register.  The girl told me huffily that "We have a system here.  You need to pay over here."  Instead of her taking my money and walking the 2 feet, I had to "excuse me/pardon me" through the crowd to get there.  To her.  I felt embarrassed for being so stupid.  ( I was also  6 months pregnant and SITTING AT THE COUNTER!)  

Finally, I understand they have a monopoly in the neighborhood, but the prices are very high.  See for yourself.   If you want any kind of specialty drink, you will have to start at around $3.95 for a small.  It doesn't matter if it has simple or complex ingredients or if they can make the batches in bulk and in advance.  (Today I had a Thai iced coffee, which I am pretty sure is just iced coffee with sweetened condensed milk added.)

The place just isn't good enough, comfortable enough, or pleasant enough to warrant the prices and service.

I will start by saying that I really enjoy the coffee. That being said, I will never spend another cent at Rocket Cat Cafe. The service has progressively gotten worse and worse in the last 3 years that I have lived in the neighborhood. Many of the barristas get more and more rude with almost every visit which alone I might be able to accept if it were not for the fact that it takes (literally, zero hyperbole) 10 minutes to receive any espresso drink. Yesterday I went in and ordered a latte. Paid for my drink ($5.05 plus a $1.00 gratuity.) I am used to waiting some time at Rocket Cat so I decided to use this time productively and walk across the street and go to the local deli to make a purchase. After waiting for the traffic light and crossing Frankford Ave. twice, going into the deli, having a short (small talk) conversation with the deli owner and making a purchase I returned to Rocket Cat. There was no one in line so I walked up to the counter and said "excuse me I ordered a latte." Before I even finished my thought the barrista grunted "Yah." while staring at me confrontationally. I tried to explain myself and said "I just walked across the street..... Once again the staff member jumped down my throat and said "She had other orders." I wanted to try and explain that I just was inquiring as to whether or not my order had been completed, but then the other barrista chimed in "that's the way it works" in a snotty childish voice. Then she STARTED to make my order. I decided to just shut up and go back outside and wait.

Whoever owns this place please take note of all the negative reviews placed previously to my entry. I would say most of those previous entries are spot on and I wish I had heeded the advice contained in those reviews. Understand that every other coffee shop is doing it better, faster and friendlier.


Reanimator cafe, Lola bean, Coffee House Too, and Steep Grind are going to be getting my $35 a week from now on.

If you find me in Rocket Cat, you will find me with a Thai iced coffee in hand  And if you find me with a Thai iced coffee, it's just a matter of time before you will find me running full speed through the streets of Fishtown trying to fight mailboxes.  Seriously. 

On the whole, their hot espresso drinks just aren't that good.  I once got a white chocolate mocha there that tasted like peanut butter.  This would have been kind of tasty if I wanted a peanut butter latte.  But I didn't.  The mochaccino was a bit muddy.  The regular iced coffee is totally adequate, but nothing special.  Iced mochas need sugar but are pretty yummy once that has been taken care of.  The Thai Iced coffee is truly where they shine.  It's so yummy, refreshing, totally addictive, and will get you amped for anything.  I've tried making it on my own and it's just not as good. 

I wouldn't recommend coming here if you're in a hurry.  Even when there's not a line, it seems like they move kind of slow.  The service is usually pretty friendly though.  While you're waiting, peep some of the pastries.  They sell some kind of chocolate brownie cookie looking round thing that is divine.

The thing I don't like about Rocket Cat is that the Thai iced coffe (wow, I am so crushing on this stuff) is not available in the winter, but summer is a-coming!  So keep your eyes peeled for the red head who is kicking mail boxes.  Say hi if you see me.

i've been coming to the Rocket Cat since 2006. in that time span, i moved from Fishtown to Massachusetts and then returned to Fishtown this past August. i now live three blocks away, but i'm not there that often. there's a good reason why.

you know, Starbucks has a bad reputation among indie types, and for (some) good reasons - you know, the faceless corporate monster, etc etc. however, one thing i can say for The Coffee Behemoth is their employees are, about 85% of the time, really nice and genuinely seem to want to help me (might be the health insurance, stock options, 401k, i dunno). 

not so at The Rocket Cat. i'll echo what has been said by most of the commenters here - their attitude generally sucks. there are some exceptions, of course, but about 85% of the time they act as if they can't be bothered. and let's be honest - most of the reason one goes into a coffee shop of any stripe is the human interaction element - the idea of being welcomed into a somewhat homey space by a nice person who makes you delicious drinks and food which you then savor. once that nice person is absent, i find it harder and harder to patronize a business, no matter how amazing the drinks/food are.

iced/hot coffee is decent. i haven't gotten their sandwiches in a while, so i can't speak to that, but they have Le Bus cookies and pastries which are HEAVENLY. my partner had a thai-style iced coffee and pronounced it delicious (but that was only after being made to feel bad / awkward by the barista because he wanted it to be decaf). 

so seriously. i hope whoever owns this place at least reads these reviews and retrains accordingly. you don't have the squash someone's soul and identity by telling them to be nice to the people who come through the door. if you think that's the case, you probably shouldn't own a coffee shop.

signed,
a cranky old person (old in this case = 31)

I'm on a binge of positive reviews.  Negative reviews are important to write, but I miss having good things to say.  Luckily, I'm spending a little quiet time in Philadelphia this week, and I seem to have hit the jackpot with Rocket Cat Cafe.  Warm, generous, open, hip space.  Coffee and food are very good.  Free wireless and plug-in's but, as with Leotah's, not at all coldly laptopp-y in feel.  And like Leotah's, this place has a beautifully alternative feel that seems to be far too short in supply in Philadelphia.  Although Rocket Cat is a genuine cafe in the sense of it's being expected that many people will simply come here for coffee and writing/surfing, the owner (or proprietor?) seems to take a kind of quiet joy in customizing items as casual as a bagel-with-avocado, or a simple sandwich, to the appetite of the eater.  More than that, she seems to have a sense of how to add small touches that make a dish great.  For example, she asked if I wanted olive oil on my avocado bagel, and this addition made the bagel totally delicious (obvious, I guess, but honestly I never thought of it).  It was just a bagel with avocado!  But she made it great.  There's also a retro wrap-around counter area with stools, and the fact that these seats are pretty regularly used seems to be a testament to the warm, kind feel of this place.  Love it.

I went into the Rocket Cat to study today and I was there for awhile before the following occurred. I was at a table with my friend and I got up to get a refill on my Tea. When I came back to sit down, I put the tea on my table then sat in the chair, and it suddenly went backwards and stopped at an angle. I thought at first that I had broken my chair, and tried to get up when I realized I was stuck at an odd angle. As a bigger person, I was at first extremely embarrassed about the situation, though honestly i've NEVER broken a chair before in my life! When I looked down I saw that the leg of my chair had fallen into a HOLE in the floor. Not the side of the floor against the wall, the side of my chair in the middle of the floor! It took  another patron to help get me up. The other patron said to me that the same thing had happened to him recently. I got up and informed the two young ladies at the bar about what happened, and I got the brush off with them saying "Oh no! We will look into that" then turning away from me.  What would have happened if I had not put my tea down before? I could have been severely burnt! Right away I started having some back pain which has gotten worse since I left. I also now have a headache. I tried to find an e-mail address for the owner but I couldn't. I will be going to the doctor on monday to get my back checked out.

I think the worst part of this embarrassing experience is that the people behind the bar didn't even do so much as to ask if I was ok? And I wasn't sitting in an out of the way table. That hole is dangerous. I also noticed one around the pipes on the other side of my table. I will continue to try and contact the owner of the shop. 

This was not my first time at Rocket Cat, and before this I have enjoyed it. The food is good, the people are usually friendly, and their tea doesn't suck which is a rarity in this area. I won't be going back though, because of the attitude of the baristas. Was it so hard to ask if I was ok, and not giggle and say "oh no!"?

After getting a styling and  profiling hair cut at Plume I was seriously in need of appeasing my daily coffee fix. Going to NoLibs wasn't an option since I needed to try something new. But that proved to be more difficult than I anticipated since Canvas Coffee Co. which was closest looked to be closed for good. Hot Potato Cafe teased me by being closed so they could load musical equipment into their space (and apparently teased me even further by not being a coffeehouse). As soon as I found it I was tempted to enter Sulimay's so I could give it a minimum of 3 smurf dances (thanks Ben - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1myUN_ES8Hw) but it just wasn't what I was looking for. 

Finally I called up friend who was able to point me in the direction of Rocket Cat just in time because I was seriously craving a cup! my first reaction was that the bike toting hipster vibe was very strong within it, but they were equally friendly with me (even if I was a sweating zombie by the time I got there.). The large coffee was a humongous and came at a decent price. And although the veggie platters looked mighty tempting I decided to go with a cookie that was the size of my fist. not only was it that large, but it had nuts, chocolate chips, and ginger inside of it. Score! The vibe and decor of the place was as artistic as it was informative and old fashioned. The couches and main counter had a vintage feel, while it was loaded with plenty of artworks and fliers for local events.

So while it looks like Fishtown might only have one decent coffeehouse (I hope I'm wrong!), at least it's an appealing one that offers a good vibe.

Well it only took me sitting here for a good 7 minutes before anyone even acknowledged my presence after the hostess sat me.  There was hardly anyone here even but lots of employees walking by me.  I knew what I wanted when I walked in the door.  Ordered eggs Benedict poached hard/done, Applewood bacon & a Salty Dog.  Bartender brings me my drink...as a shot. WTF??? She said that it said no ice when she "looked it up".  Who doesn't know what a Greyhound or a Salty Dog are?  Grapefruit/vodka & grapefruit/vodka/salt as DRINKS WITH ICE.  That's a classic drink that any bartender should know & extremely simple.  Breakfast comes.  Guy waiter sits it down in front of me because now I apparently have 2 different people waiting on me.  Eggs are runny as can be.  This is the second time this exact thing has happened to me at this place.  So they take it back to remake it.  Guy comes back and the salad that I didn't know came with this plate has onions all over it.  Well some people have allergies and I can't have onions so I ask for another salad with no onions.   Guy comes back with a bowl of lettuce DRY with nothing on it.  So I'm like:  Is this dry lettuce???  He said well you said you didn't want anything on it.  No that isn't what I said.  I said no onions but ok now you people are just being insulting!  I said: I'll just take my bill and a box to go to the guy.  Waitress comes & says do you want a box to go?  I'm all: yes because this entire experience sucked completely.  Waitress:  "Well ok then!"  She comes back with box & I start to tell her what my problem is which was pretty much everything from start to not even finishing and she doesn't want to hear what my problem is or why it was such a bad experience...she just took the Benedict off my bill and walked away.  & no I didn't take my dry lettuce stuffed into a bowl & the 1 egg Benedict I left on the plate.  This actual building is nice but the service & food are completely subpar.  That's a whole lotta NOPE!  I will never go back.

I am writing about a poor experience at this café on Saturday afternoon (April 23).  Firstly, our server never came to greet us, and when the hostess walked by, she noticed and sent her over. Once there, she informed us no one told her we were her table.  Next, we ordered the Acai Bowl, which is mostly banana whip.  I have worked in restaurants that served whip, have a whip machine at home, and had this dish there in the past so I know there was absolutely no banana in it. When the server asked us how it was, I politely told her there was no banana.  She said she would check with the kitchen and when she returned, told us there was indeed banana in it.  But then, a bus boy came to our table and told us the "recipe changed" (even though it is the same on the menu) after hearing our conversation. But finally, we overheard another server at the table right next to us tell that couple to be aware that the café has been out of bananas and could not make smoothies, etc. Wow!  We could not believe we were lied to.  And we were still charged for it!

It just got worse.  We waited a long time for our food, and when it finally came out, it was not what we ordered.  We waited some time again, and a second round of dishes came out  - not our food. We could not believe it (neither could the table next to us).  When we finally got our food, over an hour later, it was cold as if it was just sitting in the kitchen.  Once again, nothing was taken off our bill and the waitress even said to us upon leaving "lord, I feel like this café wronged you both in every way today - I do hope you will give us another try sometime." Not even a manager came over to apologize...

And to follow up, I emailed the restaurant directly about this bad experience before posting and have yet to hear anything back...

I'm going to preface this review by saying that I am thrilled to have a spot like this so close to home. The variety of offerings from one venue with hours that practically make it a 24-hour operation should yield a review of much more praise...unfortunately it falls flat. There's a lot that Front Street Cafe can be and should be doing to really make this an all-star neighborhood contender. Here's the breakdown of woo's and boo's:

CAFE: 
Woo!: I'll start here because I have great things to say about the coffee shop aspect of FSC. The house coffee is Counter Culture Hologram, a delicious cup for a very reasonable $1.75 a cup (though strangely I was charged $2.50 when ordering off of the brunch menu). The pastry case is stocked with local favorites such as Dottie's Donuts and Crust Vegan Bakery, so good that my carnivorous boyfriend was shocked when he ordered a donut only to later learn that it was vegan. The grab-and-go case has a variety of offerings including juices and pre-made salads/sandwiches, definitely a nice option to have when on the run.
Boo!: The entire FSC space is kind of just a mish-mash of usable serviceable table space, upstairs, downstairs, cafe, patio, you can sit wherever. I come here often to do work, mostly on weeknights before I go home, and I can choose to sit wherever there is an open table to set up shop and grab a cup of coffee. On weekends, however, top priority is given to someone ordering a full meal. I understand the loss of money on a table that is only ordering coffee and looking to knock out an hour or two worth of work, but being turned away doesn't make the space feel much like a comfy neighborhood cafe anymore. On my most recent visit, I asked if there was anywhere that I could get a little bit of work done and I was told no because the cafe is used for brunch from 10:00-2:00...when I told the hostess that I had every intention of ordering a meal, I was immediately given a table. Many others were turned away from sitting and having a casual cup of coffee because the entire cafe side of the house was being used to seat brunch-goers. 

FOOD: 
Woo!: While I haven't had a full dinner here, I have ordered happy hour appetizers and have had brunch on more than one occasion. For happy hour, follow the recommendation of many other reviewers and order the buffalo cauliflower, it really is delicious. Other notables for me have been the oven fried potato and the pickled veggie platter, but I'm a sucker for anything soaked in vinegar. 
Boo!: When every other negative review says that their food was cold upon arrival, you would think FSC would take note. The first time I had brunch, I ordered a salad so I couldn't speak to food temperature; on my most recent visit however, I ordered the Gravlax platter (again opting for a cold dish)...how can you mess up a cold salmon platter? Easy. You send the dish out missing the avocado listed on the menu, you inconsistently slice the salmon, and you fry the capers in what tasted to be old oil. I'll generously offer a redeeming plus one for the everything english muffin, it's about as close to a bagel as you get on their menu....I'm still confused as to why a cafe doesn't have bagels that aren't gluten free. Lastly, I wouldn't normally comment on someone else's experience, but sitting next to me was a couple whose food came out so cold that one of the two told the server that it felt like his eggs benedict had been placed in the refrigerator prior to serving. Now that's pretty bad. 

THE BAR: 
Woo!: It's a bar!
Boo!: When Front Street Cafe first opened, they had a killer happy hour. Their specialty cocktails were half priced, and select beers and wine (3 beers, 1 white wine, 1 red wine) were all $5 plus a half priced juice of the day from the cafe. I told a group of friends all about it and so we decided on this as our Friday end-of-week wind down happy hour opting to sit outside on the gorgeous patio. Sitting here meant that we had table service, which would have been fine except that our waiter didn't write down any of our orders and ended up bringing us incorrect cocktails on both rounds before we called it quits and went elsewhere. Luckily we aren't too picky, we found someone at the table who would drink what was brought out, but between the inaccurate orders and the understaffed bar, happy hour consisted of two rounds over two hours because service was just so slow. Not long after FSC opened, that happy hour disappeared. While happy hour still exists, the options are much more limited in nature; while this may mean a more manageable list for the bar and waitstaff, it's a little disappointing for patrons who may not care for the single $5 cocktail on the menu.

With a few fixes I can see FSC really knocking it out of the park, but until that happens I'll be here during off-peak hours for coffee and taking happy hour/brunch to other businesses in the neighborhood.

Came here for breakfast today.... I spent a long time working in the service industry (serving, bartending, management) That being said I understand that things can't always be perfect, but my experience kind of forced me to be "that guy" on yelp, I feel slightly robbed and Unsatisfied after this morning. 

I ordered the Veggie Hash with poached egg, Chicken Waffle bites, an order of fries with 3 of the house-made aioli (because I heard they were delicious). 

Our food came out and it was cold , happens. The chicken and waffle bites came out 5 minutes later so I'm assuming maybe the kitchen was off and the server was waiting for the entire order and our Platters were left out to dry. 

A new order was made which we appreciated, I feel we were extremely understanding and polite when we mentioned it was cold, we just wanted to get our money's worth and to experience quality since it's slightly heftier than your typical breakfast pricing..and at a diner usually things come out so hot you have to wait a minute. 

The poached eggs, hash and fries were being remade as we picked at our chicken and waffle bites, that were slightly undercooked.... maybe not but we were unable to make it through a few because they were tough and hard to chew. ( wouldn't order again) 

The food came back out but seemed like it was rushed in the cooking process ( hash should kinda have some crunch ) not the case. I would have rather waited longer a second time for the food to taste right than to have instant gratification. I'm a patient person ( this experience tested that for sure) and on top of it all it lacked flavor ... no fabrication, it was extremely undercooked and had no flavor.  The fries were forgotten about until 10 minutes before we asked for our check, with the 3 aioli just chilling there at 50cents a pop, which I totally wouldn't have minded if I actually had fries to dip into them. 

Like I said, I work in the industry. From the way it seemed, the server was spread thin and tried her best,may have not only been encountering issues with only our party. She seemed flustered, so I won't say she was being rude to us,  but she was unapologetic and barely present our entire visit ( another staff member encountered our frustration/blankly staring and silent looking confused) 

Our coffee was on the house at the end of the entire experience and our aioli was full price even though it took 1hr to get fries to go with ... I'm not broken hearted but I'm sad.

Maybe this was way to long if a review but I know that this kind of stuff can be helpful and I didn't want to just cookie cut it. I will probably be back, but I don't want you guys to get a bad reputation so I hope this feedback is helpful. 

I swear I'm not an asshole, I'm just disappointed.

Went to Front Street Cafe, last Saturday evening, with my wife, my daughter, her boyfriend, his father and his father's girlfriend.

Service was prompt, as it should be.

Drinks were excellent.

Appetizers were wonderful.

The meal, it was good for 4 out of 6 of us.

I had the hamburger, which tasted fine, but was under cooked. I asked for Medium, pink in the middle. I always say pink in the middle to the waitstaff, always. The burger was Rare in the middle, regardless, I ate it anyway. I'm not one to return ANYTHING to the kitchen - ever.

Oh yeah, before I finished ordering my hamburger, I told the waitress, or waiter, that I wanted 5 times more "Tomato Jam" than was deemed necessary - I like a lot of "Tomato Jam" on my burgers and fries. I ordered the "Wedge Potatoes" with my burger.

Waitress or Waiter - yes, there were two of them, and that may have added to some level of confusion.

Note to Front Street Cafe - One person is enough to attend to a table. If it requires Two, then they should at least be coordinated with each other. At times it seemed as if the Two waitstaff had no idea what the other one was doing.

I got my burger and it had 1 tiny metal cup of Ketchup, not "Tomato Jam" with it. And that tiny metal cup was half full. There was however a very little smear of "Tomato Jam" underneath my "Wedge Potatoes" Once again I told the waitress that I'd like additional "Tomato Jam" or Ketchup for my meal.

NONE EVER CAME.

It's not like it was a full to capacity evening at Front Street Cafe, so this shouldn't have been a difficult request to fulfill, at all.

Please don't be pretentious, don't go to all of the trouble to make and serve "Tomato Jam" people want Ketchup for their burgers and fries, Heinz Ketchup, or Hunt's Ketchup, but Ketchup. Even homemade Ketchup, as long as it's Ketchup, and not "Tomato Jam." Also, I didn't think the "Tomato Jam" was all that tasty, it lacked salt.

Some of us want LOTS OF KETCHUP. Just bring the damn bottle to the table next time.

Remember, the Chef isn't paying for the bill, the customer is. That being said, one axiom comes to mind - The Customer Is Always Right.

"Wedge Potatoes" Umm...more like Railroad Ties. Too thick, way too thick. Whatever you call them, "Wedge Potatoes" or French Fries, or if you're politically cute, and passe - Freedom Fries. They should never be thicker than my stubby little fingers - never. These almost seemed too starchy in the middle, for me, anyway.

My wife had the Organic Buttermilk Fried Chicken Sandwich, which she said was too salty for her tastes.

I would go to Front Street Cafe again, I'll just bring my own bottle of ketchup next time.

It's just nice to see something done right. A restaurant/cafe/bar/performance space seems like a recipe for disaster, but thoughtful attention to the customer experience down to small details make this place a winner. Some things I appreciated when my husband and I visited for brunch yesterday:

* It can take a while to get seated, but there's a coffee bar right there where you can order yummy drinks and smoothies while you wait. There's also some seating, which in our case was taken up by families, but is a nice touch. 

* They have a new fancy water filtration system that they seem super proud of. We were informed up front that it would be an additional $1 per person for unlimited fancy filtered water and decided to go for it. The water was tasty, and I like that they are serving healthy options that don't trash the environment. 

* The main dining area is a big, open, high-ceilinged space with hardwood floors, brick walls, metal ceilings, and lots of iron. Spaces like this always look beautiful, except that they're usually so loud you can't hear yourself think. Front Street Cafe remedied this by lining the edges of the ceiling with unobtrusive sound-insulating panels that matched the corrugated metal ceiling, keeping the aesthetic but making it easy to have a conversation. The music was also the exact right volume. It's such a small thing, but it makes such a big difference. 

* The menu was incredibly vegan-friendly but still had options for die-hard carnivores (like my husband). A place where your vegan friends and your husband who will die without red meat can dine harmoniously? Yes, please. 

* The pancakes were delicious, and were heaped with sculptural levels of fresh fruit, almond cream, granola, and real maple syrup. I don't know what that other lady is going on about. Maybe next time she should just go to IHOP. 

* Nice beer list and drinks menu. We didn't partake (it was brunch, and we had to drive), but good to know for next time. 

* Every staff member we interacted with was lovely. Personable without being smarmy, accommodating without hovering. We shared some laughs. It was nice. 

* The bathrooms are spacious and have many stalls. Again, a small thing that makes a big difference!

So yeah, Front Street Cafe is #doingitright, and definitely a place I'll want to dine again the next time I'm in Philly.

Gorgeous, HUGE place.  Interior and massive outdoors patio is what dream eateries are made of.  Cool, clean, with a little industrial, a little farmhouse. There is so much room, you feel like you can breathe, stretch out and enjoy your meal, cocktails, what have you. And folks, that's where my compliments will end. The burger was pretty good, but dang, this place needs WORK. It's been a while since I've experienced such horrendous service like what's going on here.

What absolutely ruined my experience the last time I was here, was a combined failure of front and back of house, and one where not one management person came to our table to apologize or explain, which is a big no-no in my book. Let me reiterate that prior to my current employment, I had been in the restaurant/service industry for a long time, so I'm familiar how problems like these typically get resolved.  

Set scene.  Sunday brunch. Mid-day, relatively busy, but not oppressively so. Lots of vacant tables, restaurant seemed to be well-staffed. Party of five (that includes a three year old).
Orders taken for drinks and food at the same time. Takes a good fifteen minutes to receive drink order.  Fine, it's brunch.  Food arrives perhaps another fifteen minutes later, but food runner brings me a wrong order, and the two sides we ordered for my daughter never materialize or the iced coffee that I had ordered at the outset.  

Ten minutes pass, our server absent-minded appears with no apology but says food is coming, I remind her of the missing sides (a bagel and some grits) along with my order: a vegetable sandwich. Easy peasy. I'm polite. Bagel and a veggie sandwich, kitchen should be able to slap that together rather fast? No. 

 Another ten to fifteen minutes pass and nothing. Finally the bagel for my daughter appears, few minutes later, the iced coffee is dropped off. I urge everyone to eat while it's hot, and no one really steps forward to tell us the status of the outstanding food, or apologizes - it's just an afterthought. After everyone is done, the server re-appears again without showing interest or concern.  I inform her that I'd like to take my food to go since the meal is finished. Nearly twenty minutes after everyone's food arrives, my to go container with a VEGETABLE sandwich (not a burger well done) appears. Our bill arrives and she tells us she didn't charge us for the sides (well, the one bagel we ordered) nor the sandwich and that's it.  No apology, no manager, no one. Crickets.

The food in the end, is pretty much mediocre and on the whole cold.  The burger is the most delicious item I taste at the table (and I'd reorder that in a heartbeat, if I ever was to return), and their bloody mary's, are well, absymal.  The veggie sandwich I eat once we're home, it simply that: a sad little bun that contains peppers, onions, a portabella mushroom and a couple strands of arugula. I'm told there's some salsa verde in there, but I don't taste it. Their smoothies (though crazy price-y at 8 bucks a pop) are yummy.  We were seated at the large booths that sit right at the double doors that lead outside; which annoyingly enough felt the harsh reverberations of the doors smashing open and shut every 45 seconds when service kept going in and out.

The absolute lack in professional service and/or concern was the real kicker for me here. I mean, mistakes happen.  This restaurant hasn't been open forever, but it's been long enough, that these kinds of mistakes and inconsistencies should be resolved by now, and the fact that the manager (I'm assuming it was a woman that delivered the bagel and said it was 'on her' - and who never introduced herself or made a reappearance at our table - clearly avoiding us) was entirely absent really ruined the whole dining experience for both myself and my family who was dining here for the first time.  The server could have barely given a shit, either that, or she was a very good actress. A "I'm sorry about the mistake or your order, or anything" would have been nice. But nope. Entirely unacceptable. Won't be coming back here.

The following review is for brunch:

Came here on Saturday morning as I had bookmarked this place for a while and heard great things. I am not a vegan, but lactose intolerant and have a difficult time with bread (not gluten free, just can't do a lot of bread). Let me start by saying that I had a really difficult time picking only one thing...so I didn't! Here is what I got:

1. Porridge: Oh....My.....Lord was this good. This bowl (gluten free and vegan btw) is so large and full of all of the good things your body needs. You have plant-based milk, coconut, nuts, fruits, and just general deliciousness. Not to mention that the portion is HUGE! I took like 60% of it home and had it for breakfast this morning (still good). 

2. Vegan Scrapple: I've had better but it wasn't the worst. Doesn't taste like scrapple, though. 

3. Mushroom Bacon: I'm telling you right now that I will have dirty dreams about this "bacon". As a meat eater, this bacon (while it doesn't taste 100% like bacon) is the work of a genius. How on earth did you get mushrooms to taste like that? If you don't get the bacon, you're a fool. Try it! A side is just $4! Even my mate, who got actual bacon, was surprised at how good it was. Do. It. 

4. My mate got the eggs benedict with bacon on an everything english muffin. The muffin was not your typical Thomas', but looked good. The bacon was exceptionally done, nice a crispy. However, the hollandaise looked a little TOO yellow for my fancy and...to the detriment of those like myself who love to watch a poached egg explode...the second one was cooked all the way through like a hard boiled egg. Oh well, it happens. Poaching is an art. 

For drinks, I got a cortada which was good and my  mate got a coffee which was way too bitter for my taste. He also got a Mimosa that was way overpriced but "it's okay, it's mainly champagne" he assured me. I got a glass of wine to finish off my meal that was a-okay in my book. 

Will I be back? You bet your sweet bum I will! I want to try all the things!

My company had a meeting here one afternoon around lunch time. 

We called ahead to let them know a large party would be coming, and they saved a seat for us upstairs at a large table. The upstairs is significantly smaller than downstairs but it was very quiet and there were lots of people up there studying and working, so it seemed like the right place for us to be. I want to open my review by saying that I really love the atmosphere of the restaurant.
