Like many restaurants in Northern Liberties and Fishtown, it definitely has a sort of weathered, industrial, antiquated feel to it, and I really love that aesthetic so I thought it was charming.

Our server greeted us with coffee and was very attentive. The coffee was served in these delightfully large mugs that were perfect for wrapping your hands around on a freezing cold day. I'm not an expert coffee taster by any means, but I thought that the coffee was a little too bitter even after adding sugar and cream.

We ordered buffalo and sriracha cauliflower, which unfortunately was not served until just before our entrees came out. The cauliflower itself was awesome, I am certainly not a big eater of this particular vegetable but I thought that our appetizers were really great and I would order them again. Besides being really flavorful, the cauliflower also had a nice texture, as though it were baked or fried. 

For my entree I ordered huevos rancheros. I was honestly a little bit disappointed, I thought it was a little bit small considering it was $14. It was served on a large plate and had a significant amount of fresh greens on top so it looked like a salad at first glance. Underneath the greens were the black beans, eggs, tortilla, quinoa, and other fixings. I didn't feel like the greens added anything amazing to the flavor of the meal. The entree itself was good, but felt light and didn't leave me feeling satisfied. If I go back I think I will order something different. 

Overall I really enjoyed the restaurant and I would definitely like to eat here again.

My final breakdown: 
Service: 5 out of 5
Atmosphere: 5 out of 5
Food: 3.5 out of 5
Parking: free, if you can find it

This review pertains to our happy hour/dinner experience.

My friends and I arrived around 5pm on a weekday. Immediately, we loved the ambiance of the place - so clean/modern, but cozy and inviting at the same time. Unfortunately, there wasn't much else that impressed us about Front Street Cafe.

First, they don't have a dedicated happy hour menu, although they do offer specials. There was no mention of happy hour anywhere, and our waitress never brought it up - we only knew from having visited the Facebook page prior to our visit. Even after we specifically asked about it, it took a while for us to figure out what the offerings were. One of us opted for the cucumber gimlet, and two of us got the only red wine that was included in happy hour - the Cotes du Rhone.

The good: the cucumber gimlet was delicious. The very bad: our red wine tasted straight-up rotten. This wasn't just a bitter or poorly-made wine - I've had the displeasure of accidentally ingesting rotten grapes (or rotten food in general), and the three of us all agreed that that was pretty much what this wine tasted like.

I brought up the matter to our waitress (note that I'm generally not picky at all about food, and never fuss unless there's an actual problem). She insisted that they got this complaint "all the time" and that it was just the way that the wine was - "earthy" and "vinegary." She didn't offer to taste it herself or get a second opinion, but immediately dismissed our complaint. Thankfully, she was able to take the wine off the tab, so we just left it at that.

The dinner entrees were better. My friend was satisfied with her veggie burger (quinoa + mushroom) and I enjoyed my fried chicken sandwich, although our party seemed to agree that the banh mi was rather mediocre. The oven fried potato that is offered with the sandwiches may have been my favorite part of the meal - it's a wonderful cross between a baked potato and potato chips/fries.

I wasn't sure what to make of the service. It was a little on the slow side, although we weren't there during a particularly busy time. Our waitress answered all of our questions and was reasonably nice, but I'm still bothered by her response to our wine.

Overall, I'd give the food 3.5* and service 2.5*. (I've decided to give FSC the benefit of the doubt and not take the potentially rotten wine into consideration.) Decent, but it's not good enough to make the trek from Center City/West Philly worth it.

I am hopeful that FSC will become a five star favorite of mine, but for now not so much. I've been clamoring to try it and was so excited that we finally had a Saturday available for brunch. 

First, it's gorgeous. They took their time with this place and it shows. I'd go back just for the building. I definitely want to sit in the garden and have coffee drinks, and cocktails, and dinner. But for now the main vibe I got from the place was coldness. It was a recurring theme.

Our server was disinterested and barely spoke with us except to take our order. She checked on us once the whole time. I got a hot tea and never received any sweetener and had to ask for lemon with it (from the women who delivered it). Odd. In general it seemed like we were bothering her. We sat upstairs with I think one or two other tables. Our food was also cold or room temperature. Huh? It felt like a lot of the components were premade and then assembled by the kitchen staff. My husband ordered the vegan biscuits and gravy with real poached eggs and a side of mushroom bacon. I had the tofu scramble benedict with vegan scrapple.  My dish was room temperature. The food tasted really good (save for the baked products that were dense and need some serious work). I loved my tofu scramble, hollandaise, and and vegan scrapple. The flavors were great, but served hot with a lighter muffin would've been perfection. His dish was tasty, but again the only egg was hot and it seemed the rest of the dish was reheated. The mushroom gravy was a little scarce, but delicious. The biscuit was better than my english muffin, but still pretty dense. Even the mushroom bacon was cold, and needed a little salt. It's like the smoked coconut bacon from Memphis Taproom but a little sweeter and the texture is chewier. We left full, but I think that was only because of the dense baked goods. 

Because they are so vegan and vegetarian friendly, I will definitely go back. I appreciate a business that takes the time to create an interesting and flavorful menu, but something about it seemed rush. I feel like with refinement (and a nicer server) this place could easily be five stars. Yes, it's kind of crazy expensive, including the draft list. Really? No. Not in Fishtown where you can go to so many different craft beer bars and get drafts $2-3 cheaper. Still, something about it makes me want to try again.

We originally wanted to go to One Shot Cafe the day we came here but we were not disappointed at all.

The decor and atmosphere is great! Really comforting, especially when coming in from the cold outside. As soon as you step in, you're greeted by a large lobby and bar that serves tea, coffee, and smoothies. We got teas while we waited which were fitting for the cold weather (green jade blossom).

When being seated, the area is quite small but packed. There's a homey feel to it as everyone is happy and talking away with their friends/family.

We ordered the turkey burger and all natural burger since we craved lunch food instead of breakfast food. 

You'd think that the burgers are just burgers but honestly, they were one of the best burgers I've had.

The turkey burger tasted nothing like turkey since it was so moist. I'd say it was more of a turkey patty with the texture of a breakfast sausage. Nice and spongy but without the grease! With the avocado and plentiful fries, it made a nice pairing that left you full but not sluggish (you know, the feeling after having a greasy meal).

The all natural burger was the no frills all american burger that came with bacon. I ordered it in a medium rare and it was cooked to perfection. This resulted in a nice and juicy patty that sent me to heaven whenever I took a bite. Beware though, it was extremely messy and I found my hands covered in grease/juice that made me wish I picked something else (but that's just me!). Regardless, it was an amazing burger and I'd go back just to order 2 or 3 more. 

I mentioned the fries briefly but I didn't mention they tied up the meal. Some fries are sad and soggy. Some are crunchy and stiff. These fries were right in the middle. This led to a nice soft interior but extremely crunchy exterior that created a party in your mouth whenever you had them after a bite of your burger.

Obviously, we could have gotten something different but it was 2pm by the time we got there and we were so hungry that we picked basically anything that we immediately saw.

Ok, so my first time here was not my favorite dining experience. Actually, it's my least favorite dining experience of all time!!! My car got towed (illegally come to find out) on Front Street, in front of Kung Fu Necktie across the street. Be VERY careful parking around here as the area is known for vicious tow truck companies just running away with your car! Well, one company really. A truly traumatic experience. I mean, awful!! AWFUL!! Threatened with pit-bulls, dead bolted in a room full of men in an scary neighborhood, scammed out of my money, lied to....Horrific!!! See my review for Siani's Salvage. You were warned!! I don't want to fog what will be a shining review with this negativity so I'll just leave it at that. It's truly a shame this experience has made me hesitant to return as the food and vibes were just my style....

Let's start with the ambiance which is truly great. Reclaimed wood, exposed brick, clean, bright and light, industrial chic. There's also a roof deck and courtyard which look phenomenal and I place I wood like to be in warmer weather. The flowers on the table were simple but had a little sparkle. Love that! 

We entered and moved past all of the people grabbing their morning coffees and nosh to the hostess stand. It seems like this place is a morning rush go-to for those who live nearby. I can certainly see why. I happened to catch a glimpse of the bakery case which looks filled with  delicious goods and did notice the variety of milks...soy, almond...oh yea, I'm in the right place. Excited! 

We waited about 8 minutes on a holiday Monday morning until we were seated, but not before we were asked if we had reservations (even though there were plenty of empty tables) so I'm assuming they are usually needed for brunch (?). 

We were escorted to the back room by the beautiful bar and the hostess handed my daughter crayons and a nice big coloring sheet so yea, go ahead and bring those kiddos! 

We started with the Matcha Mint Chip smoothie 
(cacao, mint, matcha, almond maple, banana, vanilla) which I thought was really great! Not too thick and full of
Minty flavor! I would definitely get it again. $8 is fairly standard for this type of drink. 

Our table of 4 split: 

The Acai Bowl- (acai banana whip, coconut, fresh seasonal fruits, nuts and seeds granola $10.) Very good.  A tad too "soupy" for me personally, but the table liked it a lot and it was tasty!

Those iconic Lean Green Hotcakes- (fresh seasonal fruits, vanilla cashew cream, maple syrup $12.) They told me the color is created by using kale juice! How clever!! They were good. The toppings were better than the actual cakes. Needed the syrup, a tad on the dry side. Would maybe give it another go. 

The tofu tacos: (tofu scramble, kale, avocado, smoked mushrooms, ``whiz``, pickled red onions, micro cilantro, corn tortillas, smoked black beans $12) DELISH!! Love the pickled red onions. Perfectly sized portion! Loved these!! A great brunch item!

The chili: (hearty lentil chili, gluten-free cornbread muffin $7.) Very tasty, filling and just the right amount of spice. Perfect for a cool day. 

Kale Caesar: (kale, walnut picada, roasted tomatoes, pickled red onions, cucumber, roasted tomato vinaigrette $10) My favorite dish of the day!! Again with those pickled red onions!! Yum! Perfect blackened tofu. Perfect dressing to kale ratio. Perfect!! Get one for the table to share!

Prices were very fair for the quality and portion sizes. 

I was very impressed by the creative, eclectic menu!! You do not have to be vegan to enjoy a meal here (they have a few options for you carnivores), but boy if you are....it's paradise!! Go for it! I wanted to sample everything and really wish to come back and do so as it all looks incredible. So many amazing options!! I have to get over the trauma of my towing experience because this place is really a treat! Highly, highly recommend, but be careful where you park!

Ambiance: Absolutely Gorgeous! Very roomy and the outdoor garden is very beautiful on this 70 degree day for brunch. 

Service: (3.5/5) I went today (4/21/2019) for Sunday Brunch with a party of 5, my GF's cousin put her name down with the hostesses (there were two of them, a male and female) and we waited. As 20 minutes went by, she went back to check and the hostess got a little hasty and just tossed the mini-clipboard menus down as if we were in the wrong when she sat us down at our table. Our waitress was friendly and is very polite! (I wish I remembered her name!) she made the experience better with her service throughout our stay. The drinks and food came out in a timely manner. 

Food: (2.5/3/5) I am NOT an expert at food rating nor am I foodie by any stretch of the means, but as I got a taste of the dishes my friends ordered, the food is pretty bland and need a little bit of seasoning. *Again, I am not an expert on judging food and this is my FIRST time here but have been to other cafes where I can respectfully compare to Front Street's Food.* Three of my friends ordered Egg's Benedict, w/a side of potatoes and the bread seemed kind of over-toasted a little bit but the rest of the components were okay. The potatoes were a bit bland. As for myself, I had the Quinoa Bean Bowl Salad (w/no add-ons) and it was pretty good as the salad that topped the tortilla was excellent and well dressed and the Quinoa bean salad's texture is thick enough to use as dip. 

Drinks: Acai Smoothie-Great, Iced Wild Berry Hibiscus Tea-Great, Peach Blossom Tea-Great, Iced Coffee-Bad, Cortado-Good. The iced coffee was a bit water down (mind you that my friend took a sip of the coffee before the ice melted). 

At the end of the experience, we did not come out too satisfied with our food as the hostess kind of put a sour beginning to our experience and the food came out pretty bland. I understand that it is Easter Sunday, it is busy but a little more effort into the food could be improved a little bit. I am not going to be harsh in saying I will never revisit, but I think Cafe Lift has this place beat by a little. I mean that in a respectful manner, since I have repeatedly went back to Cafe Lift and their food has been exceptional and consistent. Even my very first visit to there tasted like my recent visit. I do apologize for the harsh review, but Front Street Cafe just didn't live up to the 4-5 star reviews.

This used to be one of my favorite restaurants in Philly. I'm vegan and brought my friend who is extremely allergic to dairy to try French Onion Soup for the first time in her life and she was so excited. She almost immediately started having a reaction so we asked our server if it was made with real cheese by mistake. Next thing we knew the manager came over with a prepared monologue about how much they respect the vegan diet and how they would never intentionally cause someone to break their moral stance on not eating animals. It was at this point we had to ask "so what you're saying is that this is in fact real cheese?" Which she only then actually confirmed. When I informed the manager that my friend in fact was having a severe allergic reaction she shut down and all she did was ask if there was anything else she could do. We asked for Benadryl which they didn't have so we asked for directions to the closes gas station as a member of our party ran to the gas station. Meanwhile, the server game over and bragged that she definitely put in vegan and fully blamed the cook rather than acknowledging that she had any part in the matter. She didn't ask how my friend was or check to make sure she was ok (no one did). All she did was comp her $7 soup from our $100 ticket as if that absolved her of any wrongdoing. She then ignored us for 20 minutes after we'd put our card down. Our friend made it to the gas station and back before she even came back for our card which she then took ages to return. No one apologized at any point for any part of this as my friend say there in immense pain. This is the worst customer service I've ever experienced (coming from a person who professionally diffuses customer issues) and for this is why I can never return to Front Street mo matter how much I loved the food.

Let me just start by saying the Barista was terrific, courteous and friendly.

Actually my green smoothie was also excellent.


That's where the goodness ends, unfortunately.  

In these covid crazy times, I know we must be cautious.  I know businesses have to adjust their rules.

However, I walked in here (for the first time) at 4:45 on a saturday (presumably a lull since there were about 2 parties at a very big establishment with a plethora of tables.  I would say there were at least 25 tables, including a few more cafe style tables.  It's almost like the front of the restaurant fronts as a coffee shop cafe, while the back is more restaurant-like.

Here's the way the conversation went:  To the barista:

"Do you think I might be able to sit at this empty table (closest to the door) for a few minutes while I drink my smoothie and latte?"

She politely told me that I should check with the hostess first , but definitely intimated that this was a malleable policy at best.

Call over a young gentleman and ask him.  Not going to say he was unfriendly either.  He said no and also explained that allowing me to stand at the cafe counter closer to the window--would be "loitering"

while I was waiting for my latte I spoke briefly with the manager and explained that I understood policies and that they were meant to be malleable and that this particular one was short sighted when it came to business.

The optic is not good --especially when you have tons of empty tables, and 20 people standing around chatting  (there were honestly more servers congregating in the station than there were in the entire place.)

The vibe , the energy, the slight condecension I got from the manager--he would I"m sure deny it--but the energy was just off kilter in here.  

I always believe that flows from the top down.

I just think it's really shitty and bad business for a neighborhood establishment--to not think outside the box and say, "yeah, you know what, we don't make a habit of it--but given there are two people in the place and 10 servers standing around (he actually told me it was because they needed to disinfect the table after--um, cuz you don't have enough people here to do it?)

Really short sighted, really bad business, and doesn't exactly the kind of vibe that makes you want to patronize their establishment.  

Think outside the proverbial box when it comes to creating "policy." 
They are there as guidelines and meant to protect everyone--not to be put in place just because youre being a stickler and cutting off your nose to spite your face.  Would it have been any different if I had asked for a table, wasted one of your servers, tipped them anyway--for the $15 I spent?

REally kind of silly.

Went on a super cute cousin date and it was worth it. One of the best things about this place is that its outdoor seating has the best ambiance but we went on a slightly rainy/overcast day so we stayed indoors which nonetheless did not diminish our experience!

We went last Thursday for late lunch and were treated exceptionally well by our server. He was very attentive but patient with us (even though it took us quite some time to make up our minds and place our other!).

I went with the All-Natural Chicken Sandwich no pickles, add avocado, and a side of fries. Would've have gotten a perfect 10/10 if not for just two small things: the fries being too salty and the cook forgetting to remove the pickles. Still 8/10 is pretty solid! My sandwich was juicy, fulfilling, and surprisingly delicious given that it was not a the typical big deep fried super breaded chicken breast style. Adding the avocado did cost a bit much ($3.50 extra) but it was worth it, that touch of avocado was *chefs kiss*. The fries were made almost too perfection but they were a bit too generous with the salt.

My cousin got the Griddled Cheese with a side of Fries and she was very much satisfied with zero complaints. I did take a bite of her sandwich and I almost wish that I would have went with that option. It was a bit too cheesy for me but the jalapeno-tomato jam was to die for. The slight sweetness complimented the cheese so well so if you are looking for a not so basic grilled cheese I wholeheartedly recommend this! Her fries were also a bit on the salty side too but not even one was left on our plates.

We did not get any drinks besides water so I cannot make any comments/suggestions on any..(water was good but that's hard to mess up)

Overall, FSC had exceptional service, superb ambiance, and conventional dishes with delicious original twists! I wish I could give this place a 4.5 but if we are rounding up then 5 it is.

So I've been coming to this place for a long time, and I'm sure post pandemic things got a little more difficult. But I decided to dine here in a Monday night around 830, dining room was empty so was the bar. Patio look pretty lively, in my mind perfect night for good in rushed food, my girl was craving the cauliflower which is iconic. Drinks and food came out at the same time 25 minutes later. The cauliflower was very disappointing one side of the board was under cook the other side was over cooked and definitely not tossed in any salt or pepper. Had the jackfruit sandwich was in edible because the slice in the bbq sauce tasted straight like licorice and the side of kale ceaser was way to young and just couldn't get thru the stems. Also had the French onion soup which also disappointed because all I taste was straight up veggie stock nothing else. I'm am shocked and absolutely disappointed in my exp here. For a place who charges $13 for a whiskey shot of Telly should blow us back by the food. I ask to see the manager and he had poor manners and just didn't give a damn. I expected to be comped the food eh I had we didn't but still ended having a $130 tab. I have been to the place about 20 times and my girl a dozen as she is a vegetarian. Bad food and poor management this will be our last time ever dining here again and it's sad but I can't support a place who can't get their most important dish the vegetarian community rights makes no sense. For $130 and a horrible experience is insane. Also the kitchen does not wear a mask and we are required to should be thing, we've been wearing mask for over a year and a half it's nothing new or uncomfortable any more, same with the floor manager who delivered food with out one.

I went here on a Friday afternoon around 12:30. As soon as I walked up, I knew this would be my kind of place. You walk inside and are welcomed with a bright, clean, modern area. It's beautiful inside and you can tell this building has been restored. It's a twist between old and modern and they have found the perfect balance. I love the exposed brick and the metal ceilings. There is a coffee bar with fresh pastries and smoothies. There's an outside terrace area with plenty of seating. The restaurant area has a bar that you can sit at. The morning cocktails look declines.  

There was a fifteen minute wait. There was plenty of open seating but there were only 3 servers and they were staggering the tables. This place was really crowded which I knew was a good sign. We were seated and we only took a few minutes to look at the menu and ordered right away because we were starving. 

I ordered the Huevos rancheros and my dad got the peaches and cream pancakes with a side of the veggies hash. While we were ordering, the table next to us ordered and we were almost drooling, the food looked that good. That persuaded my dad to get a side of the veggie hash. Our tables was close to the kitchen and I was able to see the food being prepared and ready to be served. The french toast is so incredibly thick, the burger and chicken were giant and the salads looked so fresh. Nothing sits for long which is a sign of fresh food. 

Our food came out and it tasted as good as it looks. The Huevos rancheros was u like anything I've had before. It had a quinoa, rice and black bean mix on the bottom, topped with 2 sunny side eggs on a tortilla and then topped with fresh greens. There was some sort of spicy sauce on the side too. It was so flavorful and fresh. 

I tried the veggie hash which was delicious. But oh my, those pancakes! We looked at the menu ahead of time and were hoping for the banana pancakes but the actual menu there only had peaches and cream. Anyways, those are some of the best pancakes I've ever had. Each bite was better then the next. They are wheat pancakes topped with toasted nuts, warm cinnamon peaches and the most incredible cashew cream sauce. 

Overall, this is an amazing place to check out and I can't wait to come back. The service was great and the food is incredible!

I think regret is the best way to describe my experience at Cafe La Maude. My boyfriend and I made the spilt second decision to visit this establishment after passing by another brunch establishment. I can see why people do like this place but it's just not for me.

It's a cute little cafe with an ethnic twist. We were seated quickly by whom I am guessing was the owner. He was sitting with his family and we were seated a table down from them. I looked over the menu and my heart sunk. Nothing sounded good...but I settled on an omelette. Maybe cause I'm a vegetarian? Not sure.

The coffee arrived first which was quickly followed by the meal. The coffee here is La Columbe and it's SO good but you don't go out for brunch just for coffee. I took a few bites of my omelette and just felt sad. For ~$18 I felt more regret for choosing this location.

Parts of the meal were okay, like the fresh fruit and potatoes - these were actually very good. But the fact of the matter is I couldn't find anything on the menu that sounded good. Usually I do more research on places before just showing up but I failed to do that here. 

It makes me sad to leave this review but I really can not recommend this place.

As a long time Northern Liberties resident I am thrilled that this intimate little bistro opened within walking distance of my house. Latte Lounge, the owner-operated coffee shop that used to occupy the space was down-home beautiful, a place where neighbors would meet and greet and live jazz performances were sometimes held. It had a lot of soul, which helped me overlook just how run down it was.  When it closed a few years ago after a nearly 10 year run, I and the fam were disappointed. It wasn't perfect, but it was a place to grab a coffee, gab with the owner and a neighbor or two, and maybe read to my little girl from the generous collection of donated childrens' books.  But Cafe Maude not only brought back the sense of family that we missed, they brought a level of excellence and professionalism to the business that is very much a rarity in these parts. The space was completely gutted, the basement excavated, and a sophisticated Parisian-modern establishment cleverly shoe-horned into a modest row-home ground floor. A spectacular transformation. The owners had a lot of input in the design, but utilized a professional designer (Robin Stellwagen) to guide the planning and design process. This was a wise move, and shows in the attention to the layout, use of materials and simple but important details, like the cleanable surface on the condiment counter. As a hospitality designer I may be biased, but I have seen so many costly mistakes on DIY projects that It has become a pet peeve of mine. 

In spite of the few negative reviews about service on this blog, which I am really surprised to read, I would say that Cafe Maude's service is their strong suit. Quick and professional, and completely attentive to the customer. Very little if any barista sidetalk going on here. It is all about the customer enjoying their experience, whether it is a delicious latte with a French pastry, or a fresh omelette and salad. But I DO have to agree with a few negative reviewers who were upset with the service packs of butter and cream cheese offered. Nothing says inauthentic more than this. Take a second to apply the condiment and know your customer's preference (schmear? loaded? touch of butter?) and you will have won over your customer. I hope the owners toss out the service pack concept, which is especially jarring given how wonderful the place is otherwise.

I appreciate that Cafe Maude has a depth of staff including a charming bus person to bring food up from the kitchen and clear tables, although the owner is just as likely to do this. It also helps that they usually have more than one person behind the counter when it gets busy; a register person AND a barista. 

My colleague Zaid who is from the Middle East, loves this place and finds the dishes delicious and authentic. He not only enjoyed his lunch, but got to speak his native Arabic with the charming owner, Natalie. The design is clean and tasteful, and I am especially impressed with the a la carte kitchen and Parisian style bathroom they have carved out of the basement. Clearly the owners take great pride in their establishment and have invested a great deal of treasure in the building AND the business. Well worth a visit and a "Best of" list.

A really cool breakfast joint in Northern Liberty. The owner was super friendly and knew all his customers. The restaurant itself was classy without being overly pretentious. We had the seating by the windows and they were the best, having a lot of sunlight as you enjoy your beautiful morning breakfast.

The price was high but for the area and the quality of food, I doubt anyone is complaining. Everything on the menu looked delicious and we couldn't decide. Our waitresses was very knowledgeable and helped us picked some awesome dishes. 

We got the sweet potato benny and petit steak breakfast with a side of applewood bacon and French fries. We also ordered vanilla chai latte and the berrylicious French toast for the dessert.

If I could only use one word to describe our food, it would be "beautiful". I did not expect art on a plate for breakfast when I came here. The colors and presentation was very clean and appetizing. My sweet potato Benny plate was very good. One of my poached eggs was over cooked but everything else was simply delicious. I love that the hash were made from sweet potatoes, they added a sweet contrast to the savory Lebanese sausage. 

The petit steak breakfast had similar elements to my dish but tasted even better. The steaks were tender and perfectly seasoned. I really appreciated the fact that their hash came with mango chunks. They really nailed the balance of flavors here, sweet and savory. The French fries were very crunchy, just the way I like them. The Apple wood bacon was crisp throughout the meal. This place really knew how to elevate simple ingredients!

My vanilla chai latte was one of the best I've had and again, the presentation was just beautiful. My favorite dish however, was dessert. We had our waitress to thank for that, I apologize for not asking for her name but if the owner is reading this, just know that your waitresses were terrific.

The berrylicious French toast came with hazelnut spread and brûlée banana with finely chopped mangos and berries topped with this sweet, creamy sauce that tasted like heaven. I had no complaint on this dish whatsoever.

Overall, this was an amazing experience and I recommend everyone to check the restaurant out. The high prices mean I may not come back as often as I would like to but whenever I can, I definitely will! For those who are visiting Philly, do not leave without trying this place, you would be missing out!

I think I'm feeling 3.5 stars , but ugh thats not an option.

So I heard about this place in the strangest way. ALAS! I have to answer all sorts of sketchy calls from life. I live off of that shit.

This was where I lost my northern liberties virginity, promising I would explore more of Philly this summer and was done being foreign. I checked out the place on yelp and seemed pretty neat, right down my brunch alley [who can resist a victorian-type wallpaper?], and the mix of the two cuisine definitely had me intrigued!

They carry La Colombe coffee, which to me is always a good sign, but then again as a Latte drinker, it really depends on your barista too. The latte turned out pretty damn good, won't lie, as I am especially hard to please when it comes to coffee. Almost ordered a salad but then the devil in me wanted bread and something new, so I ordered the shrimp sandwich, forgot what the real name it, but it was VERY good, full of shrimps! Got a fresh tomato gazpacho on the side...would not recommend it, kinda bland. My friend ordered the 2eggs with Gruyere cheese and potatoes. Potatoes were to DIE for, wish i stole some more from him. Only complaint, it was inundated with cheese, maybe a little less so we could find the egg? 

I liked the atmosphere. It was one of those place where I could choose to be casual, or if I'm feeling fancy, I could roll with that too!I do have a weakness for fancy brunches! I would like to go back, but just never got around to it. For the price, I guess I was looking to be wowed a tad more? Not sure, something just did not add up, probably the guy talking about wrestling next to us, killed the whole warm and fuzzy feeling os summer :/  I liked how they had little pastries and macaroons all over the store and the open doors looking out the street and outdoor seating is definitely charming. 

I would say go check it out, if you don't absolutely love it, you will definitely have a good enough time :]

I can't believe I've never been here before! I've always been seduced by the guaranteed cheap and filling eats at the comfort food capital of Philadelphia next door, Honey's.

But I'm glad I did come here--in fact, I came here as a result of Yelp reviews too (rare for me).

Not only was I satisfied with my delicious foul moudamas (a Middle Eastern classic that I make at home, but Cafe La Maude has its own take on it fava beans over hummus, drizzled with olive oil and bright red tomatoes), the presentation is serious--I like that attention to detail. It was a bit expensive at $10.50, and like the owner told me, he prefers it "like we make it at home, too." I love the honesty and openness.

I was particularly impressed with how hospitable the owner Gabby and barista Christina were. Great people to talk to and very friendly and genuine. I felt like I was at home.

Despite not having a dedicated wait staff and needing to order at the counter, the food was delivered and my water was refilled promptly by both the owner and employee.

Christina sold me on how great the place was when she raved about how great management was and how she loved working there.

Recommended for brunch or breakfast or just coffee. Very chill and laid back, people seem to love just spending time at the beautiful cafe with its Mediterranean and European style.

The actual space doesn't afford the restaurant the luxury of having servers, but for the prices, I don't prefer to order at the counter. That's probably my only complaint. My three star review is close to four, as well. One more visit and it'll get there, I bet.

After reading an article on 10Best claiming that Café La Maude has the best brunch in Philly, I immediately decided that I needed to visit. Considering I'm a food critic (edit: basic white girl who considers brunch a birthright) I feel it my duty to issue the following PSA: 10Best's article is wrong, wrong, so wrong *Gretchen Weiner's voice* I don't think Gretchen's father, the inventor of Toaster Strudel, would be too pleased to hear that Café La Maude doesn't offer the best brunch in Philly--it offers the best brunch in the world. Save your money on plane tickets and even on your cable bill; instead, get your foreign policy on a plate in this Lebanese and French eatery. Unlike anything you'll see on a cable news channel, everything at Café La Maude is extremely easy to stomach #NOTfakenews

When I declare that everything at Café La Maude is easy to stomach, I can do it with confidence because I tried 6 things (judge me). The Open Faced Mediterranean Burrito had so many layers of flavor Trident Layers Gum should be paid a royalty. The Saumon Fume a Cheval took me so far into Flavortown I'm pretty sure I saw Guy Fieri. The Shakshuka sha-shook my tastebuds---and my exceedingly high expectations. The Berrylicious Pain Perdu? Stahppp. It was worth giving up the bikini body I never had.

The only thing I like as much as incredible food is great company. I was lucky enough to have the BEST company during my visit here--and by company, I mean the Café La Maude employees #sorrynotsorrymom We visited Café La Maude with my family to celebrate Memorial Day. After reading about the infamous wait times at Café La Maude, my sister and I arrived early to put our name in for a table. We were surprised when we were called to be seated after only a few minutes. The problem? On their way to the restaurant, my parents decided to take a leisurely, untimely, and unannounced tour of Spring Garden Street. Realizing they were going to be tardy for our party, I made the hospitable hostess aware of our predicament. The hostess, Andrea, was incredibly understanding; she allowed us to keep our place in line AND graciously worked to seat us immediately when my parents showed up (un)fashionably late. A big shout-out to Andrea--Lebron needs a lesson from you, girl, because you're the real MVP. 

Just when we thought our experience couldn't get better, we met our server Jonathan. Have you ever been referred to as a magical unicorn when you're stuffing your face like a barnyard animal? Thanks to Jonathan, I have--and it made me feel like a mix of Fergie and Jesus. Jonathan delighted my family so much I'm sure they're somewhere drafting adoption papers #StayGoldenPonyboy From the owner to the servers, every single person working in this restaurant is a gem. Not to be dramatic, but I'd take a trip to see these any of these diamonds over an engagement ring any day (just don't tell my boyfriend).

Seriously though, please recognize that I took my Yelp profile out of a 4-year hiatus to tell you about the perfect food and service at Café La Maude, which will surely result in even longer wait times here on the weekends. I'll chalk it up to being selfless AF *hopes this makes up for missing 16 years of church* Feel free to personally thank me for my sacrifice when you visit Café La Maude and it's str8 up heavenly.

Oh... Oh My. My brunch world just got turned upside down.

So, you can go and wait 1.5 hours down the street at Honey's (not that there's anything wrong with that), or you can stroll by all of the throngs of 20-30 somethings and take a seat in a seriously charming little French bistro. Not saying there was no wait at all, but with a super small dining area, there were really no more than a handful of people waiting at any one time during prime brunch hours on Sunday morning.

The walls have adorable wallpaper accented with a black chair rail and ornately framed paintings of the owners dog (who, I am told, is frequently present in the cafe). There are little high top black tables, small marble tiles on the floor, and sweet French-countryside-esque banquets holding coffee accoutrements, water pitchers, and the sweet handmade, eclectic coffee mugs which serve your perfectly brewed La Colombe roast.

On one end of the bar, logically, the end facing the large glass windows overlooking 4th St, you'll find homemade pastries and cookies in little glass domes: shortbread cookies, baklava, rugelach, and something chocolate that I probably should've bought so I could figure out what it was. They don't make the croissants in house, but it doesn't really matter--they are perfect. 

The couple that owns this place is there waiting on you hand and foot. They are kind, attentive, and make you feel like family. They'll stop by frequently enough that you are never left needing anything. Also, they are super kind to their regulars. 

When you sit, you are handed a small clipboard with the daily specials, which includes about 6-8 different plates. This is in addition to the very expansive French-Mediterranean choices that are regulars, written on the mirrored board above the bar. The options, as mentioned, are a good mix of classic French food with some Mediterranean flavors thrown in for good measure. I am told the food is French-Lebanese. I had an open faced sandwich called the "N-Liberties," two english muffins topped with hummus, avocado, fried jalapenos, caramelized onions, crumbled sausage, all topped with a fried egg. Oh and with potato pancakes on the side as well. It was absolutely to die for. My dining partners finished most every bite on their plate--a croque madame made to order with scrambled eggs instead of over easy (they will accommodate every request), and a Mediterranean open faced burrito the size of my face.

I love this place. I wanna come back every weekend. Actually, I wanna quit working normal day hours so that I can become a regular and just chill out with a perfect coffee, and a perfect pastry while doing whatever it is people do while sitting all day in coffee shops. Yeah, until now, I never wanted to be those people. This place makes me want to sit inside it all the time and become those people.

Came here a couple weeks ago for brunch as a welcome-back celebration after leaving the continent for vacation. This place's website title boasts "Philadelphia's best brunch". Wow, making some ballsy claims now, aren't we?

I chose this place on this day particularly because contrary to my usual brunch situation where I can't get my shit together until AT LEAST 2pm, I knew that I would be starting the day off early and thus, I figured my chances of getting a table at an expedited rate would be improved. 

My GF and I strolled in, and I'm going to pull a comcast timeframe rn because I don't recall specifics, but between 11am-12pm on a Sunday during the cusp of spring and therefore PRIME brunch hour. My heart sank and my stomach LURCHED when I saw the groups of people waiting by the entrance. FMLLLLL. I hate waiting, especially when my peptic ulcers are gnawing. 

Much to my astonishment, there was a seat for two that had by golly just opened up near the entrance and we were seated.......get ready for it.....IMMEDIATELY, at cafe la-fucking-maude. I must have done something good recently to deserve this good karma but god only knows what that is. OMG maybe it's bc ppl r starting to recognize me.

Anyway, the options are bountiful and with a mediterranean twist which breaks away from the usual boring brunch mold. After some serious carb indiscretions on my vacay, I needed to get back into keto ASAP so my selection was narrowed and thank god because I'm both extremely indecisive and I also have limited attention span when it comes to reading. 

Both Tinasaurus and I went with the vegetarian omelette,"quatre fromage" consisting of fontina, mozarella, gruyere and tartufa cheese with a few avocado slices on top and hugged by salad and za'atar potatoes. The omelette itself was good, I would actually prefer the avocado be immersed from the cheese within but oh well. Combo of cheeses provided a good, cheesy flavor. Fruit components was heavily represented in the salad and the dressing was tasty. I only had ONE POTATO CUBE and it was delicious. 

This place is BYOB and they give you a cute like purple bag with ice to put your 'pagne in. BYOB-ness helps shave down the bill. 

Overall this place was good and the depth and uniqueness of the menu is hard to find in Philly but I would have to respectfully disagree with the "best brunch in philly" claim however this is a SOLID brunch choice nonetheless.

Complete needle in a haystack. I found this restaurant via yelp due to the great reviews. After broswing the menu I decided that I most definitely had to try this place.

BEST DECISION I'VE MADE IN A WHILE BECAUSE THIS PLACE IS AHHH-MAZING!!!

I sincerely anticipated that it would be everything I hoped and wished for. They have outside seating, which is a plus, but not on a super hot day. For being such a small establishment, the menu is EXTENSIVE. I was shocked. It may be overwhelming to some, but not me. I need options, and they give them to you. The seating is close, but it is a café. They also have another room for seating in another room which you may not see at first. I don't know if this is policy, but we seated ourselves which was no issue at all.

And this establishment is BYOB!

I pregamed. I searched and reviewed the menu before hand. I ordered the Berrylicious Pain Perdu. This was RIGHT up my alley.

Our food came out relatively fast. My dish was PERFECT. All od the differenr fruit flavors fused together with the sweetness of the cheese, delicious. I ordered a side of turkey bacon, which i greatly appreciated that it was even available. That, could have been cooked more, but that's my bad for not asking for it to be fried hard. I tasted my friends sweet potato hash, and it was also very tasty. We had brought champagne to have mimosas. We ordered pitchers of OJ, which could have been bigger for the price, but the orange juice was fresh, and scrumptious... sooo who cares! 

The container to chill the bottles was a tad small. Our bottle barely fit in it. But one of the employees came over and said she'd have to order bigger ones so that all bottle sizes could be accommodated. When they tried to ice our bottle all of the water from the ice spilled everywhere. They cleaned it up super fast. very attentive.

Our server told us it was his first day. When it was time to pay, he somehow swiped my card twice. Once for my transaction, and once for another. I notcied this not long after i left. I called, told them what the problem was, and they took all of my information, and told me that someone else would be calling me. When i did talk to this lady, she was nice and said they'd review their transactions to give me a refund if they were at fault. This was on a Monday. She called me back Wednesday to tell me they were indeed at fault, and my card was being refunded. 

GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE! No bitterness on my end, and i completely plan on returning.

PS: All of you Green Eggs Café fans... this places compares, and KNOCKS the competition out of the roof. Wayyy better than GEC, and a wayyyy bigger menu. More space, and faster service. Definitely worth trying.

***2nd visit a week later Labor Day***

We had about an hr's wait. They chilled my bottle for me as we waited to be seated. The owner and his wife are what every business owner should be. Hospitable, kind, and they deliver EXCELLENT customer service. They talk to their customers, not on a business level, but on a friendly note. Like they appreciate your business. They stopped at our table numerous times just for small talk even tho it was super busy. That alone will keep me coming back.

This visit I insisted that my family come with me to experience this greatness. Our food took a little ling coming out, so what did they do? They gave us a free appetizer. I had the salmon burger which was DELICIOUS. The food is uncomparable to any other Mediterranean food places. Why? BECAUSE IT IS AUTHENTIC. I wouldn't be surprised if they have their mothers back in the kitchen cooking. Knowing my name from when i checked in for a table, I'm walking down the street and the owner comes running after me calling my name. I had forgotten my sunglasses. And he went out of his way and chased me down. 

I had a Salmon burger, which was so delicious. It had ginger coleslaw, which was nothing short of amazing. Also try the macaroons! Especially the passion fruit ones!

Looking at all of these rav reviews, I feel like I'm living in a post-Invasion of the Body Snatchers world. I came here once, in January of this year, and it still sticks out to me as singularly one of the worst dining experiences of recent memory. Or of all time, really. I hate the idea of giving anyone a one star review, but that's what this place deserves.

First, and this holds absolutely no bearing on my one star rating, is it's location. I've moved just outside of the city but I still don't know why I thought I could drive there and find parking at 10am on a sunday. in January. Foolish on my part. Spent at least 30min driving around looking for legal 2hr parking. At least this place doesn't take reservations so we're not actually late for anything, right?

My friend and I walk in, and the atmosphere is very cozy, euro. We're seated nearly immediately, with the request that there's space for three as we're hopeful a friend can join us after their current obligation. "No Problem!" We're sitting in the elevated bar stools/booths in the front by the counter. Out comes the menu, which despite being food obsessed, I'll admit it was difficult to envision all of the flavors presented in each option. Overwhelming but not necessarily negative. Until, of course, you see the prices. I'm more than capable of spending $25 on FOOD ONLY for myself for a brunch entree whenever I want, but damn, it had better be good. $17 for a basic omellet? Holy hell. And what made it more difficult to take in was the near CONSTANT checking in by the staff. For the first two minutes, I just figured they were being attentive, but when three different, bored looking wait staff asks if you're ready to order 8 times within 5 minutes of receiving the menu... difficult not to see it as pushy. 

After we order, the table that's very close, right next to us, gets their food. The guy tells the waitress immediately "oh, I asked for the sauce on the side" and clearly the entire plate was smothered in it. The waitress' response? "It's so good, you'll be licking it off your fingers, trust me" and walks away. I couldn't help but laugh at the absurdity of it. $23 on a meal that you're told to enjoy the way it's given to you, despite your stated preference??? 

Coffee was good, service very timely, as again, despite being readily seated, no reservations accepted and the high prices, the employees give you the feeling you're at a busy nj diner. Food was absolutely sad and disappointing. My entree came with wheat bread at the bottom...more like a pepperidge farm wheat thin sitting in a bewilderingly bland mess, soggy, but those factory holes in the "bread" were still retaining their shape. My avocado was brown. The rest...its not that I can't recall, it's more that I had no idea what I was even seeing on my plate to begin with. The only yummy part was the petite side salad which occupied no more than 1.5 square inches on my plate. As my friend and I are picking at our bizarre, expensive messes, our third friend comes in and grabs the seat at our table. We explain to him that we're just finishing up but if he didn't mind waiting for us, he can join us on our walk afterward. A waitress comes by, asks what he'd like and he pointed out that as we're halfway through our meal, he'll just take some water. "No problem!" They take our barely eaten mush away, refill my coffee and we continue our engaging conversation. Five minutes later, our check arrives. Ten minutes later, we're all settled and I'm finishing up my coffee and conversation when the owner comes by and, I fucking kid you not, ASKS US TO LEAVE. Paraphrasing: "we have so many people waiting" and, word for word "I WAS NICE ENOUGH TO ALLOW YOUR FRIEND TO SIT HERE". Excuse me??? I asked him BEFORE we were seated for a place for 3. I have not lingered past any appropriate length for brunch (that 2hr parking is a strong motivational force), we sat through a dismal meal, with pushy and hovering waitresses, and despite all of this, I STILL tipped 25% because that's what I always do as the bare minimum. I was stunned. Out of all of the restaurants I've been to all over this Earth, I have *never* been asked to leave to make room for others. And certainly not so haughtily. Sadly, I couldn't think of a way to say this to him other than "you're out of your god damn mind" so we got up and left after I had my last sip of coffee. Sadly, had he waited an additional five minutes or less, we would have been getting up on our own accord.

TLDR; what an irritating, arrogant, and unappetizing euro-fusion mess. MAYBE I was unfortunate enough to come here on an "off day" for the cooking staff, waitresses and owner, but I think it's more accurate​ to say I got a real glimpse at what this place is all about and it's garbage...not even the kind Frank Reynolds would enjoy.

I used to come to Cafe La Maude often pre-COVID and I visited recently with outdoor seating available.

The brunch here is pretty decent! The portions are large and the dishes are tasty. They really put effort in making the food presentable and unique! 

My main complaints are the service. When my friend and I arrived, the man who seemed to own the establishment (as he did not have an apron on and seemed to walk around often greeting guests) abruptly asked us how many people there were and consistently reminded us every 5 minutes that they'd get busy (with no tables available soon) if our friends didn't show up quickly. This was ok - I totally understand as a server myself that you want your guests to be aware of the situation! But what ticked us off was his demeanor. While he was rather standoffish to us, he was INCREDIBLY nice to other (Caucasian) guests who were either seated or walked in. His short and rash exchanges with us vs his courteous jokes and friendly attitude with other customers was off putting. This made us feel uncomfortable as minorities and a tad unwelcome. This was actually the second time my friend encountered this type of treatment as a minority here; she recognized the man right from when we first saw him outside. 

The other servers, however, were kind and offered excellent service when we were seated and dined! 

I would also like to note that the prices here are more expensive for brunch as opposed to other places in the city. Each dish is roughly $17-30. It's worth it for some dishes, but definitely not for others! For example, the Mediterranean Platter is literally yogurt, hummus, pita and veggies for $19.50! In this case, you'd be paying for presentation - which is totally fine but not necessarily bang for your buck. 

Lastly, parking here can be an issue sometimes! The location has no parking lot so street parking is your only option. It can be quite competitive as it's a mix of a lot of residential townhouses and a couple other eating establishments! 

Overall, it's a decent establishment but I will probably not be dining here again soon.

Just had lunch here today and I never write reviews on Yelp but I have never been treated so poorly at a restaurant that I felt compelled to write this review. I was visiting my brother who lives in the area. We were a party of 4 + a baby and we were greeted by a very friendly gentleman and was seated promptly. The place looked really cute and he seated us at the corner so we'd have more room and be more comfortable. This is where our pleasant experience stopped. 
We ordered our food and a few minutes later the waiter brought a small plate of fresh mozzarella and tomato to our table. We assumed that it was complementary and I started to feed my daughter the tomato and cheese. The waitress rudely came
Over to our table and accusingly said "did you order this?!" And I was so confused and said "no
But it was brought to our table so we assumed.." She cut me off and said that she can't take it back because we already ate it. So we said just add it to our tab, she still decided to continue to say more to make us feel really uncomfortable for HER mistake and basically make me feel guilty for feeding the food to my hungry one year old daughter. This alone spoiled our entire meal and we were not able to enjoy our lunch. She then hovered over us while we were eating our lunch and once my mom and brother finished their meals,  she immediately grabbed their plates. My mom wasn't quite finished and still had another bite or two left and she stood there until my mom finished to snatch her plate away. When we all finally finished our meals suddenly our waitress was nowhere in sight. I had to take my daughter to the front and pay where there were three waitresses who were clearly annoyed by the fact that I stood up to go and pay my check. I came back to my table and a waitress followed me. She started grabbing at the rest of our plates haphazardly asking if we needed anything else. (Uh.. You just saw me Pay the check so what else would I need?) 
I have NEVER been treated so badly at a restaurant and have never experienced such poor service in my life. It's a shame because the place is super cute and has such potential but I would never recommend this restaurant to anyone. This was a really big disappointment.

Many of my friends have recommended Cafe La Maude, so I was so excited to finally make the journey earlier this morning. Cafe La Maude is the epitome of a small European restaurant serving high quality coffee drinks and brunch foods. The menu looked absolutely overwhelming since there were so many delicious-sounding foods listed. The prices are on the higher side, but this is one of the rare occasions where I would say that the price is totally worth it.

I had the Le Chef Omelet, which was recommended to me as the best vegetarian omelet on the menu. I had to ask for a recommendation because it would have taken forever if I had to decide on my own. Absolutely loved that the servers were super helpful and accommodating to any dietary preferences or restrictions (they told me that they could make any substitutions or alterations to make something vegetarian), which is awesome, especially after having to deal with some restaurants that are really stubborn about substitutions.

The omelet dish that I received was so amazingly delicious. It came with a really refreshing side salad and fruit salad along with another side of potatoes. The presentation was Food Network worthy - I spent a good 5-10 minutes to take pictures of (and with) the beautiful dish. Regarding the flavors, I thought that the ingredients in the omelet meshed so well together. There was the slight crispiness from the cauliflower along with the creaminess of the avocado and hummus and brought together with fresh veggies and perfectly cooked egg whites. The potatoes had just the right amount of seasoning and crunch as well, and I could tell that the vegetable and fruit salad were very fresh. The portion was pretty large as well. I honestly have no negative things to say about this dish - I wish my stomach were larger so that I could have finish every last crumb! 

My sister, who is much younger and much pickier than I am, ordered the grilled cheese and a large hot chocolate. The hot chocolate was so wonderfully frothy that my sister could not have been any happier (she's a huge chocolate fan). She thought the grilled cheese had great flavor because of the really good melding together of the different cheeses that they used and wasn't too buttery.

I do think that a large part of my love for this cafe has to do with the ambiance. the decor is very cute, European, and definitely picture-worthy. There seem to be many locals who frequent this cafe, and it's very refreshing as a newcomer to see individuals coming in one-by-one, giving each other friendly hellos and chatting it up on a Wednesday morning. The owner joined many of these people in conversation, which just added to the cozy and intimate vibe of the cafe. The cafe is also pet-friendly, so my sister and I were joined by an adorable chihuahua during our brunch! 

I love all things about this cafe and think that the pleasant service and delicious food are definitely worth the price that you pay. I will undoubtedly take all my visiting friends to this cafe to show them the best of Philadelphia.

I stopped in here for brunch with a friend.   We arrived quite early on a Sunday and as a result had no problem getting a table.   (I had called ahead but there are no reservations.   However, the server indicated that before 10 or so there should not be a problem.)

We sat at one of the two marble tables near the window which was surprisingly warm for that day.   There is 1/2 booth-1/2 chair seating along the wall and mostly table seating in the rear (where there is limited natural light).   The place has that "cool vibe".   Black and white are the primary colors here with pictures of puppies along the wall in the front.

There are almost too many choices on the menu.  (I peeked before we came and still had problems choosing.)   One is better than the next.   On the breakfast all day, there is a mix of French and Middle Eastern (specifically Lebanese) influences.   We sipped coffee as we struggled with decision and this is the first time I knowingly drank LaColombe coffee.   It is rich and robust, and was very fresh.

We finally decided on the Croque Madame and the Parisian Za.    The latter was suggested by the server as it is one of their more popular selections.   This was overall a well balanced plate with a bit of fruit, a bit of salad, what was to be brioche but tasted like croissant with caramelized onion, ham, and goat cheese - I am a sucker for goat cheese - and two eggs over easy.    These eggs were perfectly cooked in butter with no signed of browning as a result of the eggs being dropped into an overheated pan.  Overall, this was  winner.  

Service was a bit overzealous.   We were asked at least 5 times by three different people how things were.   In the middle of the meal, a person we had yet to encounter decided to rearrange plates and cups for us (square plates do not work very well on small round tables).   Once, I get my plate or coffee cup, please don't touch it until I'm done with it.   It is a pet peeve of mine.  

Once we were done, we were asked if we wanted anything else.   Of course, the question was, "What else do you have?" after we had been sitting and staring a  dessert case of croissant, cookies, and mmmmmmmmmmmmmacarons.     The server started naming the flavors and we stopped her at salted caramel.   We each had one and these were the perfect foil for the coffee.

By this time the place was filled and we were getting that strong hint to leave.  I wanted to stop in the restroom before we left and as I walked to the rear a waitress, without my asking said, "All the way in the back to the right."   I mention this only because as I approached the back of the place I saw these curtains framing an open area to the left and started moving in that direction only to find myself slamming into a floor to ceiling mirror.   The woman waiting to get into the single bathroom giggled, and said, "I did the SAME thing the first time I was here."   So fellow Yelpers, watch out for the mirror all the way in the back on the left.

When I arrived back at the table they had taken my dining partner's coffee cup, but I wasn't leaving mine behind.   Two quick gulps, and we were gone.

There is a sign posted to let you know that this is not the place to bring your laptop or iPad and work as you drink the great coffee.   Eat, pay, and go.  This is understandable but also very obvious.

Food is 5 stars.  Service 4.

Parking here is challenging as this is strictly a residential neighborhood with plenty of residential garages and the driveways eliminate street parking at the driveway apron of the garage.  There is no commercial lot in sight.

So come with someone with a small car or be prepared to walk a bit, but it is definitely worth the effort.

Depending on the staff you get, your experience can be wildly different.  There are a couple of guys that have been in good spirits each time I've been there, but a weekend younger female barista and the female owner/manager are awful on the regular.  Snarky, disparaging comments, condescending attitudes in response to simple questions.  They seem to have missed the memo that they are in the food service industry and part of that is being professional and courteous.  

The first time we were there, we sat down after they showed us our table.  Then we got attitude that we're supposed to order and pay at the counter before sitting down.  Uh, ok.  Duh, stupid customers.

Another time, my father got the ice when he asked if he could add toast to his brunch.  Uh, ok. Whatever. Weird but not a deal-ender.

The last time, we brought my Pisces Midwestern Minister mother when she was visiting and when the female owner approached and asked my mom how she liked her food, my mom said that she was disappointed in the Eggs Benedict, but that it was ok.  Then my mom got raked over the coals.  The owner pounced on the opportunity, ridiculed my mother, yelled at her.  Super awesome.  The whole restaurant stopped.  We were embarrassed.  We'll never be back.

The owner said the meal was on her.  Ha!  You have to pay before you get your meal.
Know how the restaurant works before you've ever been there or risk attitude and ridicule.  Other than that it is GREAT!!! (insert glitter and stars and happy faces)

I went to this restaurant based on good Yelp reviews. However, I was really disappointed. While the food is adequate it is not five stars and the service left a lot to be desired.

We sat in their outdoor seating area and did appreciate how warm it was. But that is where my appreciation ended. Both of our servers were wearing masks but the masks were really chin diapers and I had to ask for them to wear them properly.  This was necessary because while the seating is outdoors it is not open on all sides so the ventilation is not great. I can only assume that they are required to wear masks but don't really want to and no one is supervising them. 

When we had questions about items on the menu neither server knew much about them. I asked that my beverage be brought with my food but it didn't come at that time and no one came to check on us so I didn't get it until I was almost finished eating. I had wanted either decaf coffee or decaf cappuccino and they had no decaf beverage. I was there at 2 pm. Some people don't want caffeine at that time of day.

We had the open face Mediterranean burrito and the Berrylicious Pain Perdu. The burrito was different and tasted good but didn't blow me away. The bread in the Pain Perdu was too dense for the dish but the flavor was okay. 

I might go back and try other things on the menu in the hope that maybe other dishes are better. However, I would not go back unless I called first to request that their employees follow proper Covid protocol because I don't know if they are vaccinated and without wearing their masks properly they are breathing on my food when they serve it.

As you'll see in my profile I have left very few reviews below 3 stars and never for a beautiful restaurant with excellent food. Our party of 2 arrived for brunch on a Saturday at 11:40 AM and we were seated at 12:00PM. We ordered coffees and food and were finished eating at 12:40 PM. As we continued to sip our coffees at 12:50PM we were politely asked by our waiter to vacate the table because people were waiting - while we still had coffee left. While I understand the business wants to serve as many patrons as possible, as a paying customer that waited like everyone else my experience was completely ruined by being asked to leave while still enjoying my coffee. I understand the restaurant is busy - however the restaurant needs to better manage the situation in a way that doesn't involve displacing paying guests. The eat, pay, and get out philosophy of this restaurant is not enjoyable for me personally, especially in a restaurant that advertises its Parisian influences where meals often last many hours. I will not be back.

Great food was overshadowed by the homophobic service. My girlfriend and I were holding hands during our meal and our waitress Kiana (sp?) glared at us, rolled her eyes, and shot eye daggers from across the room throughout our entire meal. We gave her the benefit of the doubt, thinking maybe she was tired, but she was sweet to neighboring tables and started throwing food down at us and ignoring us when we said thank you making requests.

When we brought this to the attention of management, they told us we were misinterpreting the situation and that the entire staff was staring at us because we spelled the alphabet in ASL. They were belittling, tokenized their "racially diverse, Muslim, Black, Mexican" staff, etc, as evidence that they could never have a homophobic staff member in their ranks, and then went so far as to drag out their "favorite gay barista" from behind the counter to tell us they couldn't possibly be anti-lesbian (because we're all the same and no one has ever fetishized gay men, of course). Kiana never apologized, they didn't comp anything, and the female manager asked us for hugs. The male manager then followed us into the store next door to tell us that the woman couldn't possibly be homophobic because she has a lesbian family member. 

Well I guess no gay person has ever been rejected by their family, so that settles it!

Once you walk in, the decor is everything! Loved the dessert display and the picture frames of dogs. 

However, the food was okay. Nothing great. I ordered poached eggs with canadian bacon and the egg was not poached. It was soft boiled so i didn't get that oozing effect that a poached egg would give you which was disappointing. 

The food wasnt the worst part. The customer service was. Our server (male) handed us the menu and left without explaining anything on the special menu. I didnt even realize that there was a special menu until i looked at the chalk board 10 mins later and the server caught me looking at it and then he began to explain. Later when we began to order, my boyfriend asked the server whats the dish that the girl got next to us and he was clueless. You can tell he was not sure and he just guessed. But later he found out and my boyfriend ordered that dish. No problems with his dish. 

Another thing that bothered me is when four women came to sit down next to us and the same server greet them with a smile and told them the special menu and even asked them if they had any questions they could let him know. But not once did he greet us with a smile or explain anything on the menu. And Im not sure if they have two different sizes of orange juice, but i just saw this couple with a larger glass cup of oj when i passed by. My bf got a small dinky plastic cup and the price was still $3 something. Not a very good first impression at all. 

Overall the food is okay but the customer service was horrible and it wasnt even that busy...i would have given them a 1 star for customer service and 3 stars for food. Do yourself a favor and go next door to Honey Sit'N Eat. Much better food and service. People are way friendly over there too. Will not return to this place. Nope.

Brunch was good but definitely can't afford to come back for breakfast for a $20+ price tag for each dish. The menu changed quite a bit and with the increased prices It wants to be up there with places like Parc but the atmosphere is lacking as we were placed in a corner of half window, sun beam in eyes, wobbly table, awkward seating with one facing in to the restaurant and one facing sideways, and sharing our space with all the staff drinks they kept placing on our window shelf as they were sipping and working. 
I don't know about you but I don't feel like sharing space with half drunk iced coffees and Red Bulls with a $60 brunch price after tip. Also no coffee refill on my cup so when it got kinda cold after just a quarter dipped. Sorry. That's another $3.50.  
The red shakshuka was good but very sweet and I'm not sure if it tasted more canned tomato used than fresh  tomatoes. 

My eggs with roasted sweet potato was also good. 
Underwhelming with that price tag and dodgy atmosphere

I've been going to Soy Cafe for about 5 years now and it's easily one of my favorite cafes in the city.  I have horrible food allergies and an extremely restricted diet.  I initially went to Soy Cafe way back when because of their name figuring it was a place I could find some good vegan food.

When I saw that the menu included TWENTY TWO smoothies made with soy milk and honey I was so happy.  I am a huge smoothie fan!  My favorite smoothie is the Milk Vanilla:  peach, banana, vanilla, soy milk, honey.  Note for vegans who don't eat honey:  good maple syrup is available to substitute.  I always get the soy protein add-on.  It makes the smoothie richer and creamier (thus yummier).  :)  The Milk Vanilla + soy protein became my favorite smoothie of all time upon first sip.  I've been ordering this smoothie for over 5 years on a regular basis and have been impressed by the consistency shown by the staff.  They always make it the same way every time:  just right.  Highly recommend coming here for your smoothie fix!

And there's more!  :)

The salads are phenomenal.  Very generously sized and brimming with perfect, delicious, extremely fresh veggies (and fruit in some!).  My favorite is the Avocado Grapefruit Salad...even though I can't have grapefruit.  The staff is always happy to substitute apples, oranges, or another fruit of my choice.  This salad comes with a bed mixed field greens, a sliced avocado, grapefruit, thin long curly tendrils of crisp carrots and beets, sliced cucumber, sliced tomato, and a generous sprinkling of toasted almonds.  This salad also might come with peppers and onions but I can't have those so I always ask for those to be held.  The dressing is house made fresh from scratch daily.  It's an apple carrot ginger dressing that is amazing!

If you are going to enjoy a hot tea I highly recommend the Green Tea with Roasted Rice.  The roasted rice gives the green tea a light nutty note that is particularly lovely.  It pairs especially well with one of the Sweet Toasts:  Honey Nut (sliced bananas, toasted almond chips, honey) or the Elvis Special (sliced bananas and peanut butter).  Choices of bread include Russian Black, whole wheat, and multigrain.  Tea is served by the pot or the cup if you stay - I prefer to get the pot.  It's definitely not too much for one person if you're planning to take your time and relax.  It's great for 2 people as well.

The Vanilla Oatmeal with honey soy milk is phenomenal.  I know, it's just oatmeal but...wow.  I got it one morning on a whim and was like, this is the best oatmeal I have ever had EVER.  It's just...so, so good.  Perfect comfort breakfast on a rainy morning!

Soy Cafe also offers some really unique coffee drinks.  For an especially indulgent treat I love the Espresso Milkshake (shot of espresso, 2 scoops of soy ice cream, soy milk, honey)!  It's decadent, delicious, and perfect for a hot day.  The Vanilla Java (shot of espresso, vanilla, cinnamon, soy milk, honey) tastes exotic.  I prefer this drink hot but you can choose to have it served cold, blended with ice.  The Mocha-cha-cha (shot of espresso, cocoa, soy milk, honey) has just the right amount of cocoa in it - it's like hot chocolate and espresso had a baby!  Yum.  All coffee is Fair Trade organic.  Inquire about specific varieties.

The Soy Special Drinks have some big winners too.  The Soy Chai has harmonious, balanced notes that come together with the soy milk perfectly.  Nothing is overdone (I really hate too much cinnamon or too much clove, yuck!).  The Cocoa Mint Soy is like a Girlscout's Thin Mint in beverage form.  Yum!

There are always freshly baked vegan and non-vegan treats at the counter.  They are kept separate from each other which someone like me with food allergies really appreciates.  :)  Baked goods vary by the day but there are muffins (gluten free sometimes!), chocolate chip cookies, cupcakes, brownies, and more.  There are even mini cupcakes and muffins so if you are trying to keep to a diet you can still have a little something sweet with your coffee/tea/etc.  And they are just so cute!  :)  My favorites are the cupcakes.  Ahhh, so moist and such yummy frosting!

And there is so much more:  wraps, homemade soy milk, fresh squeezed veggie & fruit juices, soups, sandwiches...  I could go on forever, lol!

The staff is always super friendly and helpful.  The decor is charming and welcoming.  The atmosphere is laid back and comfortable.  There is free unlimited wifi.  Go solo, go with your other half, go with a group of friends - this cafe is great for grabbing a quick bite or hanging out for a while.  There is even a little outdoor garden!

I really love Soy Cafe.  I can't say enough great things about this wonderful place!  If you don't live nearby it's worthy of making a special trip there.  Plus there is plenty to do in NoLibs after you've had your fill at Soy Cafe, especially on N 2nd Street right where Soy Cafe is located. Highly, highly recommended!

This place has easily the worst service of any establishment in the history of establishments.  They are the Comcast of coffee.  Sadly, I'm a regular at soy and go almost everyday since July 2016.  It's at least a 10 minute wait for a coffee.  Yes, 10 minute minimum to put coffee in the cup.  But don't worry, the employees will look very busy while they ignore you.   Decided today, after waiting 20 minutes for the coffee, that I'm never coming here again.

I've been here 3 times so far with the intention to continue coming back so long as they keep doing what they're doing. Quite a cozy spot on 2nd and Fairmount, never too crowded, and a pretty extensive veggie/vegan menu. So far I've had:

--Tomato and Avocado Sandwhich on Wheat, which is a nice option for light lunch but enough to fill you up if you're not a big eater. Also served with a salad and a homemade dressing which is fantastic.
-- Miso + Steamed Dumplings - This was incredible. Great miso broth, served in a very large bowl with I think around 6 dumplings, which are also quite excellent. Will order that again for sure. 
-- Seitan Cheesesteak Wrap - I had to try this to see what it was all about. I've seen it as the special every time I go in there, figure lots of people are ordering it, and now I can see why. I like their wraps because there's a full salad in there. I cut mine up so getting bits of the wrap, salad, and seitan on a fork full is a perfect bite. Not too heavy which was my initial concern. Their honey mustard dressing is also to die for. Wish there was a little bit more of that for extra dipping. 
-- BBQ Pork Wrap - Tried this yesterday. Not bad.. I think I liked the seitan cheesesteak wrap better, but worth trying if you're looking to sample veggie proteins. 

The food is a perfect veggie lunch and is also prepared and served in a way I can respect. Decent portion, home made, and overall has a certain care for the way it's put on the plate. I also like coming here because because of the atmosphere. It's quiet, friendly, and comfortable. Will come back and try everything else in due time!
